   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading">Spain</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="vector-body"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="contentSub2"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav"></div> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" lang="en" dir="ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       This article is about the country. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Spain_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Spain (disambiguation)">Spain (disambiguation)</a>.
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       "España" redirects here. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Espa%C3%B1a_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="España (disambiguation)">España (disambiguation)</a>.
      </div> 
      <p class="mw-empty-elt"> </p> 
      <div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">
       Country in Southwestern Europe
      </div> 
      <p><span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r994658806">.mw-parser-output .geo-default,.mw-parser-output .geo-dms,.mw-parser-output .geo-dec{display:inline}.mw-parser-output .geo-nondefault,.mw-parser-output .geo-multi-punct{display:none}.mw-parser-output .longitude,.mw-parser-output .latitude{white-space:nowrap}</style><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Spain&amp;params=40_N_4_W_type:country_region:ES"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">40°N</span> <span class="longitude">4°W</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">40°N 4°W</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">40; -4</span></span></span></a></span></span></span> </p>

            <li style="white-space:nowrap;">—61% <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_Spain" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholicism in Spain">Roman Catholic</a></li>

            <li style="white-space:nowrap;">34% <a href="/wiki/Irreligion_in_Spain" title="Irreligion in Spain">No religion</a></li>
            <li style="white-space:nowrap;">3% <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Spain" title="Religion in Spain">Others</a></li>
            <li style="white-space:nowrap;">1% No answer</li>
           </ul>
          </div></td>
        </tr>

         <td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/.es" title=".es">.es</a><sup id="cite_ref-e_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-e-19">[g]</a></sup></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p><b>Spain</b> (Spanish: <i lang="es">España</i>, <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish" title="Help:IPA/Spanish">[esˈpaɲa]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Es-Espa%C3%B1a.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/64/Es-Espa%C3%B1a.ogg" class="internal" title="Es-España.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>), formally the <b>Kingdom of Spain</b><sup id="cite_ref-auto_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-20">[13]</a></sup> (Spanish: <i lang="es">Reino de España</i>),<sup id="cite_ref-a_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-a-2">[a]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-b_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-b-3">[b]</a></sup> is a country in <a href="/wiki/Southwestern_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Southwestern Europe">Southwestern Europe</a> with some pockets of territory across the <a href="/wiki/Strait_of_Gibraltar" title="Strait of Gibraltar">Strait of Gibraltar</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-20">[13]</a></sup> Its continental European territory is situated on the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a>. Its territory also includes two <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelagos</a>: the <a href="/wiki/Canary_Islands" title="Canary Islands">Canary Islands</a> off the coast of <a href="/wiki/North_Africa" title="North Africa">North Africa</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Balearic_Islands" title="Balearic Islands">Balearic Islands</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a>. The African <a href="/wiki/Exclave" class="mw-redirect" title="Exclave">exclaves</a> of <a href="/wiki/Ceuta" title="Ceuta">Ceuta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Melilla" title="Melilla">Melilla</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pe%C3%B1%C3%B3n_de_V%C3%A9lez_de_la_Gomera" title="Peñón de Vélez de la Gomera">Peñón de Vélez de la Gomera</a><sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[14]</a></sup> make Spain the only European country to have a physical border with an African country (<a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[h]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Plazas_de_soberan%C3%ADa" title="Plazas de soberanía">Several small islands</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Alboran_Sea" title="Alboran Sea">Alboran Sea</a> are also part of Spanish territory. <a href="/wiki/Peninsular_Spain" title="Peninsular Spain">The country's mainland</a> is bordered to the south and east by the Mediterranean Sea; to the north and northeast by <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andorra" title="Andorra">Andorra</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Biscay" title="Bay of Biscay">Bay of Biscay</a>; and to the west and northwest by <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portugal</a> and the Atlantic Ocean respectively. </p>
      <p>With an area of 505,990&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (195,360&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), Spain is the largest country in <a href="/wiki/Southern_Europe" title="Southern Europe">Southern Europe</a>, the second-largest country in <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western Europe</a> and the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_countries_by_area" title="List of European countries by area">fourth-largest country by area</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">European continent</a>. With a population exceeding 47.3 million, Spain is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_countries_by_population" title="List of European countries by population">sixth-most populous</a> country in Europe, and the <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union#List" title="Member state of the European Union">fourth-most populous</a> country in the European Union. Spain's capital and largest city is <a href="/wiki/Madrid" title="Madrid">Madrid</a>; other major <a href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_in_Spain" title="List of metropolitan areas in Spain">urban areas</a> include <a href="/wiki/Barcelona" title="Barcelona">Barcelona</a>, <a href="/wiki/Valencia" title="Valencia">Valencia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seville" title="Seville">Seville</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zaragoza" title="Zaragoza">Zaragoza</a>, <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A1laga" title="Málaga">Málaga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Murcia" title="Murcia">Murcia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Palma_de_Mallorca" title="Palma de Mallorca">Palma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Las_Palmas_De_Gran_Canaria" class="mw-redirect" title="Las Palmas De Gran Canaria">Las Palmas de Gran Canaria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bilbao" title="Bilbao">Bilbao</a>. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Anatomically_modern_human" class="mw-redirect" title="Anatomically modern human">Anatomically modern humans</a> first arrived in the Iberian Peninsula around 42,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-Lillios2019_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lillios2019-23">[15]</a></sup> Various cultures developed in the region with the migration and settlement of peoples including <a href="/wiki/Phoenicia" title="Phoenicia">Phoenicians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Greeks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celts</a> and <a href="/wiki/Carthaginian_Iberia" title="Carthaginian Iberia">Carthaginians</a>. The Romans had driven the Carthaginians out of the Iberian peninsula by 206 BC, and divided it into two administrative provinces, <i><a href="/wiki/Hispania_Ulterior" title="Hispania Ulterior">Hispania Ulterior</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Hispania_Citerior" title="Hispania Citerior">Hispania Citerior</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Flower2014_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Flower2014-24">[16]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BlaggMillett2016_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BlaggMillett2016-25">[17]</a></sup> Spain remained under Roman rule until <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Western_Roman_Empire" title="Fall of the Western Roman Empire">the collapse of the Western Roman Empire</a> in the fourth century, which ushered in <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic</a> tribal confederations from Central Europe. The <a href="/wiki/Visigoths" title="Visigoths">Visigoths</a> emerged as the dominant faction by the fifth century, with <a href="/wiki/Visigothic_Kingdom" title="Visigothic Kingdom">their kingdom</a> spanning much of the peninsula. </p>
      <p>In the early eighth century, the Visigothic Kingdom was conquered by the <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate" title="Umayyad Caliphate">Umayyad Caliphate</a>, ushering in over 700 years of <a href="/wiki/Al-Andalus" title="Al-Andalus">Muslim rule.</a> During this period, <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Spain" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamic Spain">Islamic Spain</a> became a major economic and intellectual center, with the city of Cordoba being among the largest and richest in Europe. Several Christian kingdoms emerged in the northern periphery of Iberia, chief among them <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Le%C3%B3n" title="Kingdom of León">León</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Castile" title="Kingdom of Castile">Castile</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Aragon" title="Kingdom of Aragon">Aragon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Portugal" title="Kingdom of Portugal">Portugal</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Navarre" title="Kingdom of Navarre">Navarre</a>. Over the next seven centuries, an intermittent southward expansion of these kingdoms—metahistorically framed as a reconquest, or <i lang="es" title="Spanish-language text"><a href="/wiki/Reconquista" title="Reconquista">Reconquista</a></i>—culminated with the Christian seizure of the last Muslim polity, the <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Granada" title="Emirate of Granada">Nasrid Kingdom of Granada</a>, in 1492. That same year, <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Columbus" title="Christopher Columbus">Christopher Columbus</a> arrived in the <a href="/wiki/New_World" title="New World">New World</a> on behalf of the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Monarchs" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic Monarchs">Catholic Monarchs</a>, whose dynastic union of Castile and Aragon is sometimes considered the emergent Spain as a unified country. From the 16th until the early 19th century, Spain ruled <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">one of the largest empires in history</a>, which was among the first <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_empires" title="List of largest empires">global empires</a>; its immense cultural and linguistic legacy includes over 570 million <a href="/wiki/Hispanophone" title="Hispanophone">Hispanophones</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[18]</a></sup> making Spanish the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_languages_by_number_of_native_speakers" title="List of languages by number of native speakers">second-most spoken native language</a>. Spain hosts the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Spain" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Spain">third-largest</a> number of <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Sites" class="mw-redirect" title="World Heritage Sites">World Heritage Sites</a>. </p>
      <p>Spain is a <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">secular</a> <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_democracy" class="mw-redirect" title="Parliamentary democracy">parliamentary democracy</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">parliamentary monarchy</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Constitucion1978_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitucion1978-27">[19]</a></sup> with King <a href="/wiki/Felipe_VI_of_Spain" class="mw-redirect" title="Felipe VI of Spain">Felipe VI</a> as <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>. It is a highly <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed country</a><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[20]</a></sup> and a <a href="/wiki/High_income_country" class="mw-redirect" title="High income country">high income country</a>, with the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">fourteenth-largest economy by nominal GDP</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">sixteenth-largest by PPP</a>. Spain is a member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> (UN), the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> (EU), the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">Eurozone</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> (CoE), the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Ibero-American_States" title="Organization of Ibero-American States">Organization of Ibero-American States</a> (OEI), the <a href="/wiki/Union_for_the_Mediterranean" title="Union for the Mediterranean">Union for the Mediterranean</a>, the <a href="/wiki/North_Atlantic_Treaty_Organization" class="mw-redirect" title="North Atlantic Treaty Organization">North Atlantic Treaty Organization</a> (NATO), the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" class="mw-redirect" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> (OECD), <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe</a> (OSCE), the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">Schengen Area</a>, the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (WTO) and many other international organisations. While not an official member, Spain has a "Permanent Invitation" to the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a> summits, participating in every summit, which makes it a <i>de facto</i> member of the group.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[21]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading">

      </div> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2> 
      <p>The origins of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman</a> name <i><a href="/wiki/Hispania" title="Hispania">Hispania</a></i>, and the modern <i>España</i>, are uncertain, although the Phoenicians and Carthaginians referred to the region as <i>Spania</i>, therefore the most widely accepted etymology is a <a href="/wiki/Semitic_languages" title="Semitic languages">Semitic</a>-<a href="/wiki/Phoenician_language" title="Phoenician language">Phoenician</a> one.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[22]</a></sup> There have been a number of accounts and hypotheses of its origin: </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:The_Lady_of_Elche,_once_polychrome_stone_bust_discovered_by_chance_in_1897_at_L%27Alc%C3%BAdia,_believed_to_be_a_piece_of_Iberian_sculpture_from_the_4th_century_BC,_National_Archaeological_Museum_of_Spain,_Madrid_(20098349590).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/The_Lady_of_Elche%2C_once_polychrome_stone_bust_discovered_by_chance_in_1897_at_L%27Alc%C3%BAdia%2C_believed_to_be_a_piece_of_Iberian_sculpture_from_the_4th_century_BC%2C_National_Archaeological_Museum_of_Spain%2C_Madrid_%2820098349590%29.jpg/170px-thumbnail.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="212" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/The_Lady_of_Elche%2C_once_polychrome_stone_bust_discovered_by_chance_in_1897_at_L%27Alc%C3%BAdia%2C_believed_to_be_a_piece_of_Iberian_sculpture_from_the_4th_century_BC%2C_National_Archaeological_Museum_of_Spain%2C_Madrid_%2820098349590%29.jpg/255px-thumbnail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/The_Lady_of_Elche%2C_once_polychrome_stone_bust_discovered_by_chance_in_1897_at_L%27Alc%C3%BAdia%2C_believed_to_be_a_piece_of_Iberian_sculpture_from_the_4th_century_BC%2C_National_Archaeological_Museum_of_Spain%2C_Madrid_%2820098349590%29.jpg/340px-thumbnail.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3178" data-file-height="3955"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:The_Lady_of_Elche,_once_polychrome_stone_bust_discovered_by_chance_in_1897_at_L%27Alc%C3%BAdia,_believed_to_be_a_piece_of_Iberian_sculpture_from_the_4th_century_BC,_National_Archaeological_Museum_of_Spain,_Madrid_(20098349590).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Lady_of_Elche" title="Lady of Elche">Lady of Elche</a>, possibly depicting <a href="/wiki/Tanit" title="Tanit">Tanit</a>, from <a href="/wiki/Carthaginian_Iberia" title="Carthaginian Iberia">Carthaginian Iberia</a>, 4th century BC
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> scholar <a href="/wiki/Antonio_de_Nebrija" title="Antonio de Nebrija">Antonio de Nebrija</a> proposed that the word <i>Hispania</i> evolved from the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_language" title="Iberian language">Iberian</a> word <i><a href="/wiki/Hispalis" class="mw-redirect" title="Hispalis">Hispalis</a></i>, meaning "city of the western world". </p>
      <p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Jes%C3%BAs_Luis_Cunchillos&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jesús Luis Cunchillos (page does not exist)">Jesús Luis Cunchillos</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">&nbsp;[<a href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jes%C3%BAs_Luis_Cunchillos" class="extiw" title="es:Jesús Luis Cunchillos">es</a>]</span> argued that the root of the term <i>span</i> is the <a href="/wiki/Phoenician_language" title="Phoenician language">Phoenician</a> word <i>spy</i>, meaning "to forge metals". Therefore, <i>i-spn-ya</i> would mean "the land where metals are forged".<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[23]</a></sup> It may be a derivation of the Phoenician <i>I-Shpania</i>, meaning "island of rabbits", "land of rabbits" or "edge", a reference to Spain's location at the end of the Mediterranean; Roman coins struck in the region from the reign of <a href="/wiki/Hadrian" title="Hadrian">Hadrian</a> show a female figure with a rabbit at her feet,<sup id="cite_ref-burke_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-burke-32">[24]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Strabo" title="Strabo">Strabo</a> called it the "land of the rabbits".<sup id="cite_ref-Spain_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Spain-33">[25]</a></sup> The word in question (compare modern Hebrew <i>Shafan</i>) actually means "<a href="/wiki/Hyrax" title="Hyrax">Hyrax</a>", possibly due to Phoenicians confusing the two animals.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[26]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><i>Hispania</i> may derive from the poetic use of the term <i><a href="/wiki/Hesperia_(mythology)" title="Hesperia (mythology)">Hesperia</a></i>, reflecting the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Greek</a> perception of Italy as a "western land" or "land of the setting sun" (<i>Hesperia</i>, <i>Ἑσπερία</i> in <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>) and Spain, being still further west, as <i>Hesperia ultima</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-anthon_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-anthon-35">[27]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There is the claim that "Hispania" derives from the <a href="/wiki/Basque_language" title="Basque language">Basque</a> word <i>Ezpanna</i> meaning "edge" or "border", another reference to the fact that the Iberian Peninsula constitutes the southwest corner of the European continent.<sup id="cite_ref-anthon_35-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-anthon-35">[27]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Two 15th-century Spanish Jewish scholars, <a href="/wiki/Isaac_Abravanel" class="mw-redirect" title="Isaac Abravanel">Don Isaac Abravanel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Solomon_ibn_Verga" title="Solomon ibn Verga">Solomon ibn Verga</a>, gave an explanation now considered folkloric. Both men wrote in two different published works that the first Jews to reach Spain were brought by ship by Phiros who was confederate with the king of Babylon when he laid siege to Jerusalem. Phiros was a <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">Grecian</a> by birth, but who had been given a kingdom in Spain. Phiros became related by marriage to Espan, the nephew of king Heracles, who also ruled over a kingdom in Spain. Heracles later renounced his throne in preference for his native Greece, leaving his kingdom to his nephew, Espan, from whom the country of <i>España</i> (Spain) took its name. Based upon their testimonies, this eponym would have already been in use in Spain by c. 350 BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[28]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Spain" title="History of Spain">History of Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:AltamiraBison.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/AltamiraBison.jpg/220px-AltamiraBison.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="179" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/AltamiraBison.jpg/330px-AltamiraBison.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/AltamiraBison.jpg/440px-AltamiraBison.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2436"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:AltamiraBison.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Reproduction of the <a href="/wiki/Altamira_Cave" class="mw-redirect" title="Altamira Cave">Altamira Cave</a> paintings,<sup id="cite_ref-Science2012_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Science2012-37">[29]</a></sup> in <a href="/wiki/Cantabria" title="Cantabria">Cantabria</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Iberia enters written records as a land populated largely by the <a href="/wiki/Iberians" title="Iberians">Iberians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Basques" title="Basques">Basques</a> and <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celts</a>. Early on its coastal areas were settled by <a href="/wiki/Phoenicians" class="mw-redirect" title="Phoenicians">Phoenicians</a> who founded Western Europe's most ancient cities <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A1diz" title="Cádiz">Cádiz</a> and <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A1laga" title="Málaga">Málaga</a>. Phoenician influence expanded as much of the Peninsula was eventually incorporated into the <a href="/wiki/Carthaginian_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Carthaginian Empire">Carthaginian Empire</a>, becoming a major theatre of the <a href="/wiki/Punic_Wars" title="Punic Wars">Punic Wars</a> against the expanding <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>. After an <a href="/wiki/Roman_conquest_of_Hispania" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman conquest of Hispania">arduous conquest</a>, the peninsula came fully under <a href="/wiki/Hispania" title="Hispania">Roman rule</a>. During the early Middle Ages it came under <a href="/wiki/Visigothic_Kingdom" title="Visigothic Kingdom">Visigothic</a> rule, and then much of it was conquered by <a href="/wiki/Muslim" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim">Muslim</a> invaders from <a href="/wiki/North_Africa" title="North Africa">North Africa</a>. In a <a href="/wiki/Reconquista" title="Reconquista">process that took centuries</a>, the small Christian kingdoms in the north gradually regained control of the peninsula. The last Muslim state <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Granada" class="mw-redirect" title="Fall of Granada">fell in 1492</a>, the same year Columbus reached the Americas. A <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">global empire</a> began which saw Spain become the strongest kingdom in Europe, the leading world power for one and a half centuries, and the largest overseas empire for three centuries. </p>
      <p>Continued wars and other problems eventually led to a diminished status. The <a href="/wiki/Peninsular_War" title="Peninsular War">Napoleonic conflict in Spain</a> led to chaos, triggering independence movements that tore apart most of the empire and left the country politically unstable. Spain suffered a devastating <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Civil_War" title="Spanish Civil War">civil war</a> in the 1930s and then came under the rule of an <a href="/wiki/Francoist_Spain" title="Francoist Spain">authoritarian government</a>, which oversaw a period of stagnation that was followed by a surge in the growth of the economy. Eventually, democracy was <a href="/wiki/Spanish_transition_to_democracy" title="Spanish transition to democracy">restored</a> in the form of a parliamentary constitutional monarchy. Spain joined the European Union, experiencing a cultural renaissance and steady economic growth until the beginning of the 21st century, that started a new globalised world with economic and ecological challenges. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory_and_pre-Roman_peoples">Prehistory and pre-Roman peoples</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_Iberia" title="Prehistoric Iberia">Prehistoric Iberia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:2014_Castro_de_Santa_Trega._Galiza-2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/2014_Castro_de_Santa_Trega._Galiza-2.jpg/220px-2014_Castro_de_Santa_Trega._Galiza-2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/2014_Castro_de_Santa_Trega._Galiza-2.jpg/330px-2014_Castro_de_Santa_Trega._Galiza-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/2014_Castro_de_Santa_Trega._Galiza-2.jpg/440px-2014_Castro_de_Santa_Trega._Galiza-2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5225" data-file-height="3483"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:2014_Castro_de_Santa_Trega._Galiza-2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Celtic castro in Galicia
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Archaeological research at <a href="/wiki/Archaeological_Site_of_Atapuerca" class="mw-redirect" title="Archaeological Site of Atapuerca">Atapuerca</a> indicates the Iberian Peninsula was populated by <a href="/wiki/Hominid" class="mw-redirect" title="Hominid">hominids</a> 1.2&nbsp;million years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[30]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Atapuerca_Mountains" title="Atapuerca Mountains">Atapuerca</a> fossils have been found of the earliest known <a href="/wiki/Hominins" class="mw-redirect" title="Hominins">hominins</a> in Europe, the <a href="/wiki/Homo_antecessor" title="Homo antecessor">Homo antecessor</a>. Modern humans first arrived in Iberia, from the north on foot, about 35,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[31]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag failed verification of its source citation(s). (January 2016)">failed verification</span></a></i>]</sup> The best known artefacts of these prehistoric human settlements are the famous paintings in the <a href="/wiki/Altamira_(cave)" class="mw-redirect" title="Altamira (cave)">Altamira cave</a> of Cantabria in northern Iberia, which were created from 35,600 to 13,500 <a href="/wiki/Before_Common_Era" class="mw-redirect" title="Before Common Era">BCE</a> by <a href="/wiki/Cro-Magnon" class="mw-redirect" title="Cro-Magnon">Cro-Magnon</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Science2012_37-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Science2012-37">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[32]</a></sup> Archaeological and genetic evidence suggests that the Iberian Peninsula acted as one of several major refugia from which northern Europe was repopulated following the end of the <a href="/wiki/Quaternary_glaciation" title="Quaternary glaciation">last ice age</a>. </p>
      <p>The largest groups inhabiting the Iberian Peninsula before the Roman conquest were the <a href="/wiki/Iberians" title="Iberians">Iberians</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celts</a>. The Iberians inhabited the Mediterranean side of the peninsula, from the northeast to the southeast. The Celts inhabited much of the inner and Atlantic sides of the peninsula, from the northwest to the southwest. <a href="/wiki/Basque_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Basque people">Basques</a> occupied the western area of the Pyrenees mountain range and adjacent areas, the Phoenician-influenced <a href="/wiki/Tartessos" title="Tartessos">Tartessians</a> culture flourished in the southwest and the <a href="/wiki/Lusitanians" title="Lusitanians">Lusitanians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vettones" title="Vettones">Vettones</a> occupied areas in the central west. Several cities were founded along the coast by <a href="/wiki/Phoenicia" title="Phoenicia">Phoenicians</a>, and trading outposts and colonies were established by <a href="/wiki/Greek_colonies" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek colonies">Greeks</a> in the East. Eventually, Phoenician-<a href="/wiki/Carthaginians" class="mw-redirect" title="Carthaginians">Carthaginians</a> expanded inland towards the meseta; however, due to the bellicose inland tribes, the Carthaginians got settled in the coasts of the Iberian Peninsula. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Roman_Hispania_and_the_Visigothic_Kingdom">Roman Hispania and the Visigothic Kingdom</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Hispania" title="Hispania">Hispania</a> and <a href="/wiki/Visigothic_Kingdom" title="Visigothic Kingdom">Visigothic Kingdom</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Teatro_de_M%C3%A9rida,_Espa%C3%B1a,_2017_18.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Teatro_de_M%C3%A9rida%2C_Espa%C3%B1a%2C_2017_18.jpg/220px-Teatro_de_M%C3%A9rida%2C_Espa%C3%B1a%2C_2017_18.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Teatro_de_M%C3%A9rida%2C_Espa%C3%B1a%2C_2017_18.jpg/330px-Teatro_de_M%C3%A9rida%2C_Espa%C3%B1a%2C_2017_18.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Teatro_de_M%C3%A9rida%2C_Espa%C3%B1a%2C_2017_18.jpg/440px-Teatro_de_M%C3%A9rida%2C_Espa%C3%B1a%2C_2017_18.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="3000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Teatro_de_M%C3%A9rida,_Espa%C3%B1a,_2017_18.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Roman_Theatre_(M%C3%A9rida)" title="Roman Theatre (Mérida)">Roman Theatre</a> in <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A9rida,_Spain" title="Mérida, Spain">Mérida</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>During the <a href="/wiki/Second_Punic_War" title="Second Punic War">Second Punic War</a>, roughly between 210 and 205&nbsp;BC the expanding <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">Roman Republic</a> captured Carthaginian trading colonies along the Mediterranean coast. Although it took the Romans nearly two centuries to complete the <a href="/wiki/Roman_conquest_of_the_Iberian_peninsula" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman conquest of the Iberian peninsula">conquest of the Iberian Peninsula</a>, they retained control of it for over six centuries. Roman rule was bound together by law, language, and the <a href="/wiki/Roman_road" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman road">Roman road</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-hispania_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hispania-41">[33]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The cultures of the Celtic and Iberian populations were gradually <a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Hispania" title="Romanization of Hispania">Romanised</a> (Latinised) at different rates depending on what part of <a href="/wiki/Hispania_Baetica" title="Hispania Baetica">Hispania</a> they lived in, with local leaders being admitted into the Roman aristocratic class.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[i]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-country_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-country-43">[34]</a></sup> Hispania served as a granary for the Roman market, and its harbours exported gold, <a href="/wiki/Wool" title="Wool">wool</a>, <a href="/wiki/Olive_oil" title="Olive oil">olive oil</a>, and wine. Agricultural production increased with the introduction of irrigation projects, some of which remain in use. Emperors <a href="/wiki/Hadrian" title="Hadrian">Hadrian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trajan" title="Trajan">Trajan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Theodosius_I" title="Theodosius I">Theodosius I</a>, and the philosopher <a href="/wiki/Seneca_the_Younger" title="Seneca the Younger">Seneca</a> were born in Hispania.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[j]</a></sup> Christianity was introduced into Hispania in the 1st century AD and it became popular in the cities in the 2nd century AD.<sup id="cite_ref-country_43-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-country-43">[34]</a></sup> Most of Spain's present languages and religion, and the basis of its laws, originate from this period.<sup id="cite_ref-hispania_41-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hispania-41">[33]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Concil_Toled.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Concil_Toled.jpg/170px-Concil_Toled.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="151" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Concil_Toled.jpg/255px-Concil_Toled.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Concil_Toled.jpg/340px-Concil_Toled.jpg 2x" data-file-width="367" data-file-height="325"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Concil_Toled.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Reccared_I" title="Reccared I">Reccared I</a> and bishops during <a href="/wiki/Councils_of_Toledo" title="Councils of Toledo">Council III of Toledo</a>, 589. <a href="/wiki/Codex_Vigilanus" title="Codex Vigilanus">Codex Vigilanus</a>, fol. 145, <a href="/wiki/Real_Biblioteca_de_San_Lorenzo_de_El_Escorial" class="mw-redirect" title="Real Biblioteca de San Lorenzo de El Escorial">Biblioteca del Escorial</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The weakening of the Western Roman Empire's jurisdiction in Hispania began in 409, when the <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic</a> <a href="/wiki/Suebi" title="Suebi">Suebi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vandals" title="Vandals">Vandals</a>, together with the <a href="/wiki/Sarmatian" class="mw-redirect" title="Sarmatian">Sarmatian</a> <a href="/wiki/Alans" title="Alans">Alans</a> entered the peninsula at the invitation of a Roman usurper. These tribes had crossed the <a href="/wiki/Rhine" title="Rhine">Rhine</a> in early 407 and ravaged <a href="/wiki/Gaul" title="Gaul">Gaul</a>. The Suebi established a kingdom in what is today modern <a href="/wiki/Galicia_(Spain)" title="Galicia (Spain)">Galicia</a> and northern <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portugal</a> whereas the Vandals established themselves in southern Spain by 420 before crossing over to North Africa in 429 and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Carthage_(439)" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Carthage (439)">taking</a> Carthage in 439. As the western empire disintegrated, the social and economic base became greatly simplified: but even in modified form, the successor regimes maintained many of the institutions and laws of the late empire, including Christianity and assimilation to the evolving Roman culture. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Corona_de_(29049230050).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Corona_de_%2829049230050%29.jpg/130px-Corona_de_%2829049230050%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="130" height="271" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Corona_de_%2829049230050%29.jpg/195px-Corona_de_%2829049230050%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Corona_de_%2829049230050%29.jpg/260px-Corona_de_%2829049230050%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1439" data-file-height="3000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Corona_de_(29049230050).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Votive_crown" title="Votive crown">Votive crown</a> of <a href="/wiki/Reccesuinth" class="mw-redirect" title="Reccesuinth">Reccesuinth</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Treasure_of_Guarrazar" title="Treasure of Guarrazar">Treasure of Guarrazar</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Byzantine" class="mw-redirect" title="Byzantine">Byzantines</a> established an occidental province, <a href="/wiki/Spania" title="Spania">Spania</a>, in the south, with the intention of reviving Roman rule throughout Iberia. Eventually, however, Hispania was reunited under <a href="/wiki/Visigothic_Kingdom" title="Visigothic Kingdom">Visigothic rule</a>. These <a href="/wiki/Visigoths" title="Visigoths">Visigoths</a>, or Western Goths, after <a href="/wiki/Sack_of_Rome_(410)" title="Sack of Rome (410)">sacking Rome</a> under the leadership of <a href="/wiki/Alaric_I" title="Alaric I">Alaric</a> (410), turned towards the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Athaulf" title="Athaulf">Athaulf</a> for their leader, and occupied the northeastern portion. <a href="/wiki/Wallia" title="Wallia">Wallia</a> extended his rule over most of the peninsula, keeping the Suebians shut up in Galicia. <a href="/wiki/Theodoric_I" title="Theodoric I">Theodoric I</a> took part, with the Romans and Franks, in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Catalaunian_Plains" title="Battle of the Catalaunian Plains">Battle of the Catalaunian Plains</a>, where <a href="/wiki/Attila" title="Attila">Attila</a> was routed. <a href="/wiki/Euric" title="Euric">Euric</a> (466), who put an end to the last remnants of Roman power in the peninsula, may be considered the first monarch of Spain, though the Suebians still maintained their independence in Galicia. Euric was also the first king to give written laws to the Visigoths. In the following reigns the Catholic kings of France assumed the role of protectors of the Hispano-Roman Catholics against the Arianism of the Visigoths, and in the <a href="/wiki/Franco-Visigothic_Wars" title="Franco-Visigothic Wars">wars</a> which ensued <a href="/wiki/Alaric_II" title="Alaric II">Alaric II</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amalaric" title="Amalaric">Amalaric</a> lost their lives. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Athanagild" title="Athanagild">Athanagild</a>, having risen against King <a href="/wiki/Agila" title="Agila">Agila</a>, called in the Byzantines and, in payment for the succour they gave him, ceded to them the maritime places of the southeast (554). <a href="/wiki/Liuvigild" title="Liuvigild">Liuvigild</a> restored the political unity of the peninsula, subduing the Suebians, but the religious divisions of the country, reaching even the royal family, brought on a civil war. <a href="/wiki/St._Hermengild" class="mw-redirect" title="St. Hermengild">St. Hermengild</a>, the king's son, putting himself at the head of the Catholics, was defeated and taken prisoner, and suffered martyrdom for rejecting communion with the Arians. <a href="/wiki/Recared" class="mw-redirect" title="Recared">Recared</a>, son of Liuvigild and brother of St. Hermengild, added religious unity to the political unity achieved by his father, accepting the Catholic faith in the <a href="/wiki/Third_Council_of_Toledo" title="Third Council of Toledo">Third Council of Toledo</a> (589). The religious unity established by this council was the basis of that fusion of Goths with Hispano-Romans which produced the Spanish nation. <a href="/wiki/Sisebut" title="Sisebut">Sisebut</a> and <a href="/wiki/Suintila" title="Suintila">Suintila</a> completed the expulsion of the Byzantines from Spain.<sup id="cite_ref-Spain_33-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Spain-33">[25]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Intermarriage between Visigoths and Hispano-Romans was prohibited, though in practice it could not be entirely prevented and was eventually legalised by Liuvigild.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[35]</a></sup> The Spanish-Gothic scholars such as <a href="/wiki/Braulio_of_Zaragoza" title="Braulio of Zaragoza">Braulio of Zaragoza</a> and <a href="/wiki/Isidore_of_Seville" title="Isidore of Seville">Isidore of Seville</a> played an important role in keeping the classical <a href="/wiki/Greco-Roman_world" title="Greco-Roman world">Greek and Roman culture</a>. Isidore was one of the most influential clerics and philosophers in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a> in Europe, and his theories were also vital to the conversion of the Visigothic Kingdom from an <a href="/wiki/Arianism" title="Arianism">Arian</a> domain to a Catholic one in the <a href="/wiki/Councils_of_Toledo" title="Councils of Toledo">Councils of Toledo</a>. Isidore created the first western <a href="/wiki/Etymologiae" title="Etymologiae">encyclopedia</a> which had a huge impact during the Middle Ages.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[36]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Muslim_era_and_Reconquista">Muslim era and Reconquista</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Al-Andalus" title="Al-Andalus">Al-Andalus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Reconquista" title="Reconquista">Reconquista</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Mort_de_Roland.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Mort_de_Roland.jpg/220px-Mort_de_Roland.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="179" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Mort_de_Roland.jpg/330px-Mort_de_Roland.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Mort_de_Roland.jpg/440px-Mort_de_Roland.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1716" data-file-height="1397"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Mort_de_Roland.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The death of the <a href="/wiki/Franks" title="Franks">Frankish</a> leader <a href="/wiki/Roland" title="Roland">Roland</a> defeated by a <a href="/wiki/Basque_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Basque people">Basque</a> and <a href="/wiki/Muslim" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim">Muslim</a>-<a href="/w/index.php?title=Mulwallad&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mulwallad (page does not exist)">Mulwallad</a> (<a href="/wiki/Banu_Qasi" title="Banu Qasi">Banu Qasi</a>) alliance at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Roncevaux_Pass_(778)" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Roncevaux Pass (778)">Battle of Roncevaux Pass (778)</a> originated the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Navarre" title="Kingdom of Navarre">Kingdom of Navarre</a> led by <a href="/wiki/%C3%8D%C3%B1igo_Arista_of_Pamplona" title="Íñigo Arista of Pamplona">Íñigo Arista</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In the 8th century, nearly all of the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a> was <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_conquest_of_Hispania" title="Umayyad conquest of Hispania">conquered</a> (711–718) by largely <a href="/wiki/Moorish" class="mw-redirect" title="Moorish">Moorish</a> <a href="/wiki/Muslim" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim">Muslim</a> armies from North Africa. These conquests were part of the expansion of the <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate" title="Umayyad Caliphate">Umayyad Caliphate</a>. Only a small area in the mountainous north-west of the peninsula managed to resist the initial invasion. Legend has it that <a href="/wiki/Julian,_Count_of_Ceuta" title="Julian, Count of Ceuta">Count Julian</a>, the governor of Ceuta, in revenge for the violation of his daughter, <a href="/wiki/Florinda_la_Cava" title="Florinda la Cava">Florinda</a>, by King <a href="/wiki/Roderic" title="Roderic">Roderic</a>, invited the Muslims and opened to them the gates of the peninsula. </p>
      <p>Under <a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">Islamic law</a>, Christians and <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">Jews</a> were given the subordinate status of <a href="/wiki/Dhimmi" title="Dhimmi">dhimmi</a>. This status permitted Christians and Jews to practice their religions as <i><a href="/wiki/People_of_the_Book" title="People of the Book">People of the Book</a></i> but they were required to pay a special tax and had legal and social rights inferior to those of Muslims.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[37]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[38]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Conversion to <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> proceeded at an increasing pace. The <i><a href="/wiki/Muwallad" title="Muwallad">muladíes</a></i> (Muslims of ethnic <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian</a> origin) are believed to have formed the majority of the population of Al-Andalus by the end of the 10th century.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-chap2_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chap2-50">[40]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Muslim community in the Iberian Peninsula was itself diverse and beset by social tensions. The <a href="/wiki/Berber_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Berber people">Berber people</a> of North Africa, who had provided the bulk of the invading armies, <a href="/wiki/Berber_Revolt" title="Berber Revolt">clashed with the Arab leadership</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[k]</a></sup> Over time, large Moorish populations became established, especially in the <a href="/wiki/Guadalquivir_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Guadalquivir River">Guadalquivir River</a> valley, the coastal plain of <a href="/wiki/Valencian_Community" title="Valencian Community">Valencia</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ebro_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Ebro River">Ebro River</a> valley and (towards the end of this period) in the mountainous region of <a href="/wiki/Granada" title="Granada">Granada</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-chap2_50-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chap2-50">[40]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Cordoba_sal.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Cordoba_sal.jpg/220px-Cordoba_sal.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Cordoba_sal.jpg/330px-Cordoba_sal.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Cordoba_sal.jpg/440px-Cordoba_sal.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="480"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Cordoba_sal.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Mosque%E2%80%93Cathedral_of_C%C3%B3rdoba" title="Mosque–Cathedral of Córdoba">Great Mosque of Córdoba</a> is among the <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_oldest_mosques" title="List of the oldest mosques">oldest mosque buildings in the world</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/C%C3%B3rdoba,_Spain" title="Córdoba, Spain">Córdoba</a>, the capital of the caliphate since <a href="/wiki/Abd-ar-Rahman_III" class="mw-redirect" title="Abd-ar-Rahman III">Abd-ar-Rahman III</a>, was the largest, richest and most sophisticated city in western Europe. Mediterranean trade and cultural exchange flourished. Muslims imported a rich intellectual tradition from the Middle East and North Africa. Some important philosophers at the time were <a href="/wiki/Averroes" title="Averroes">Averroes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ibn_Arabi" title="Ibn Arabi">Ibn Arabi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Maimonides" title="Maimonides">Maimonides</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Romanisation_(cultural)" class="mw-redirect" title="Romanisation (cultural)">Romanised</a> cultures of the Iberian Peninsula interacted with Muslim and Jewish cultures in complex ways, giving the region a distinctive culture.<sup id="cite_ref-chap2_50-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chap2-50">[40]</a></sup> Outside the cities, where the vast majority lived, the land ownership system from Roman times remained largely intact as Muslim leaders rarely dispossessed landowners and the introduction of new crops and techniques led to an expansion of agriculture introducing new produces which originally came from Asia or the former territories of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[41]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the 11th century, the Muslim holdings fractured into rival <a href="/wiki/Taifa" title="Taifa">Taifa</a> states (Arab, Berber, and Slav),<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[42]</a></sup> allowing the small Christian states the opportunity to greatly enlarge their territories.<sup id="cite_ref-chap2_50-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chap2-50">[40]</a></sup> The arrival from North Africa of the Islamic ruling sects of the <a href="/wiki/Almoravids" class="mw-redirect" title="Almoravids">Almoravids</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Almohads" class="mw-redirect" title="Almohads">Almohads</a> restored unity upon the Muslim holdings, with a stricter, less tolerant application of Islam, and saw a revival in Muslim fortunes. This re-united Islamic state experienced more than a century of successes that partially reversed Christian gains. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Leon_(San_Isidoro,_pante%C3%B3n).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Leon_%28San_Isidoro%2C_pante%C3%B3n%29.jpg/220px-Leon_%28San_Isidoro%2C_pante%C3%B3n%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="162" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Leon_%28San_Isidoro%2C_pante%C3%B3n%29.jpg/330px-Leon_%28San_Isidoro%2C_pante%C3%B3n%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Leon_%28San_Isidoro%2C_pante%C3%B3n%29.jpg/440px-Leon_%28San_Isidoro%2C_pante%C3%B3n%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1632" data-file-height="1203"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Leon_(San_Isidoro,_pante%C3%B3n).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Basilica_of_San_Isidoro" class="mw-redirect" title="Basilica of San Isidoro">Basilica of San Isidoro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Le%C3%B3n_(Spain)" class="mw-redirect" title="León (Spain)">León</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <i><a href="/wiki/Reconquista" title="Reconquista">Reconquista</a></i> (Reconquest) was the centuries-long period in which Christian rule was re-established over the Iberian Peninsula. The Reconquista is viewed as beginning with the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Covadonga" title="Battle of Covadonga">Battle of Covadonga</a> won by <a href="/wiki/Pelagius_of_Asturias" title="Pelagius of Asturias">Don Pelayo</a> in 722 and was concurrent with the period of Muslim rule on the Iberian Peninsula. The Christian army's victory over Muslim forces led to the creation of the Christian <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Asturias" title="Kingdom of Asturias">Kingdom of Asturias</a> along the northwestern coastal mountains. Shortly after, in 739, Muslim forces were driven from <a href="/wiki/Galicia_(Spain)" title="Galicia (Spain)">Galicia</a>, which was to eventually host one of medieval Europe's holiest sites, <a href="/wiki/Santiago_de_Compostela" title="Santiago de Compostela">Santiago de Compostela</a> and was incorporated into the new Christian kingdom. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Leon1030.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Leon1030.jpg/220px-Leon1030.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="167" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Leon1030.jpg/330px-Leon1030.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Leon1030.jpg/440px-Leon1030.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1149" data-file-height="870"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Leon1030.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>In 1030, the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Navarre" title="Kingdom of Navarre">Kingdom of Navarre</a> controlled the <a href="/wiki/Count_of_Aragon" class="mw-redirect" title="Count of Aragon">Count of Aragon</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Count_of_Castile" class="mw-redirect" title="Count of Castile">Count of Castile</a>, who later became major kingdoms of its time.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Vikings invaded Galicia in 844, but were heavily defeated by <a href="/wiki/Ramiro_I_of_Asturias" title="Ramiro I of Asturias">Ramiro I of Asturias</a> at <a href="/wiki/A_Coru%C3%B1a" title="A Coruña">A Coruña</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Haywood_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Haywood-54">[43]</a></sup> Many of the Vikings' casualties were caused by the Galicians' <a href="/wiki/Ballista" title="Ballista">ballistas</a> – powerful torsion-powered projectile weapons that looked rather like giant crossbows.<sup id="cite_ref-Haywood_54-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Haywood-54">[43]</a></sup> 70 Viking ships were captured and burned.<sup id="cite_ref-Haywood_54-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Haywood-54">[43]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[44]</a></sup> Vikings raided Galicia in 859, during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Ordo%C3%B1o_I_of_Asturias" title="Ordoño I of Asturias">Ordoño I of Asturias</a>. Ordoño was at the moment engaged against his constant enemies the Moors; but a count of the province, Don Pedro, attacked the Vikings and defeated them.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[45]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Le%C3%B3n" title="Kingdom of León">Kingdom of León</a> was the strongest Christian kingdom for centuries. In 1188 the first modern parliamentary session in Europe was held in <a href="/wiki/Le%C3%B3n_(Spain)" class="mw-redirect" title="León (Spain)">León</a> (<a href="/wiki/Cortes_of_Le%C3%B3n" class="mw-redirect" title="Cortes of León">Cortes of León</a>). The <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Castile" title="Kingdom of Castile">Kingdom of Castile</a>, formed from Leonese territory, was its successor as strongest kingdom. The kings and the nobility fought for power and influence in this period. The example of the Roman emperors influenced the political objective of the Crown, while the nobles benefited from <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">feudalism</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Petronila_Ramon_Berenguer.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Petronila_Ramon_Berenguer.jpg/150px-Petronila_Ramon_Berenguer.jpg" decoding="async" width="150" height="154" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Petronila_Ramon_Berenguer.jpg/225px-Petronila_Ramon_Berenguer.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Petronila_Ramon_Berenguer.jpg/300px-Petronila_Ramon_Berenguer.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1072" data-file-height="1098"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Petronila_Ramon_Berenguer.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Petronilla_of_Aragon" title="Petronilla of Aragon">Petronilla of Aragon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ramon_Berenguer_IV,_Count_of_Barcelona" title="Ramon Berenguer IV, Count of Barcelona">Ramon Berenguer IV, Count of Barcelona</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Muslim armies had also moved north of the Pyrenees but they were defeated by Frankish forces at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Tours" title="Battle of Tours">Battle of Poitiers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Francia" title="Francia">Frankia</a> and pushed out of the very southernmost region of France along the seacoast by the 760s. Later, <a href="/wiki/Franks" title="Franks">Frankish</a> forces established <a href="/wiki/Marca_Hispanica" class="mw-redirect" title="Marca Hispanica">Christian counties</a> on the southern side of the Pyrenees. These areas were to grow into the kingdoms of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Navarre" title="Kingdom of Navarre">Navarre</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Aragon" title="Kingdom of Aragon">Aragon</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[46]</a></sup> For several centuries, the fluctuating frontier between the Muslim and Christian controlled areas of Iberia was along the <a href="/wiki/Ebro" title="Ebro">Ebro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Douro" title="Douro">Douro</a> valleys. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Transmission_of_the_Classics" class="mw-redirect" title="Transmission of the Classics">Islamic transmission of the classics</a> is among the main <a href="/wiki/Islamic_contributions_to_Medieval_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamic contributions to Medieval Europe">Islamic contributions to Medieval Europe</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Old_Spanish" title="Old Spanish">Castilian</a> language—more commonly known (especially later in history and at present) as "Spanish" after becoming the national language and <i><a href="/wiki/Lingua_franca" title="Lingua franca">lingua franca</a></i> of Spain—evolved from <a href="/wiki/Vulgar_Latin" title="Vulgar Latin">Vulgar Latin</a>, as did other <a href="/wiki/Romance_languages" title="Romance languages">Romance languages</a> of Spain like the <a href="/wiki/Old_Catalan" title="Old Catalan">Catalan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Astur-Leonese" class="mw-redirect" title="Astur-Leonese">Asturian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Galician-Portuguese" title="Galician-Portuguese">Galician</a> languages, as well as other Romance languages in Latin Europe. <a href="/wiki/Basque_language" title="Basque language">Basque</a>, the only non-Romance language in Spain, continued evolving from Early Basque to Medieval. The <i><a href="/wiki/Glosas_Emilianenses" title="Glosas Emilianenses">Glosas Emilianenses</a></i> (found at the <a href="/wiki/Monasteries_of_San_Mill%C3%A1n_de_la_Cogolla" title="Monasteries of San Millán de la Cogolla">Monasteries of San Millán de la Cogolla</a> and written in Latin, Basque and Romance) hold a great value as one of the first written examples of Iberian Romance.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[47]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The break-up of <a href="/wiki/Al-Andalus" title="Al-Andalus">Al-Andalus</a> into the competing taifa kingdoms helped the long embattled Iberian Christian kingdoms gain the initiative. The capture of the strategically central city of <a href="/wiki/Toledo,_Spain" title="Toledo, Spain">Toledo</a> in 1085 marked a significant shift in the balance of power in favour of the Christian kingdoms. Following a great Muslim resurgence in the 12th century, the great Moorish strongholds in the south fell to Castile in the 13th century—Córdoba in 1236 and <a href="/wiki/Seville" title="Seville">Seville</a> in 1248. The <a href="/wiki/County_of_Barcelona" title="County of Barcelona">County of Barcelona</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Aragon" title="Kingdom of Aragon">Kingdom of Aragon</a> entered in a dynastic union and gained territory and power in the Mediterranean. In 1229 <a href="/wiki/Majorca" class="mw-redirect" title="Majorca">Majorca</a> was conquered, so was <a href="/wiki/Valencia" title="Valencia">Valencia</a> in 1238. In the 13th and 14th centuries, the <a href="/wiki/Marinid" class="mw-redirect" title="Marinid">Marinid</a> dynasty of <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a> invaded and established some enclaves on the southern coast but failed in their attempt to re-establish North African rule in Iberia and were soon driven out. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:TumboAKing.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/TumboAKing.jpg/220px-TumboAKing.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="243" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/TumboAKing.jpg/330px-TumboAKing.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/TumboAKing.jpg/440px-TumboAKing.jpg 2x" data-file-width="630" data-file-height="695"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:TumboAKing.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Portrait of <a href="/wiki/Alfonso_X" class="mw-redirect" title="Alfonso X">Alfonso X</a> of Castile and Leon from the codex Tumbo 'A' de Santiago (Dated between 1229 and 1255)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>After 781 years of <a href="/wiki/Muslim" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim">Muslim</a> presence in Spain, the last <a href="/wiki/Nasrid_dynasty" title="Nasrid dynasty">Nasrid</a> sultanate of <a href="/wiki/Granada" title="Granada">Granada</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Tributary_(political)" class="mw-redirect" title="Tributary (political)">tributary state</a> would finally surrender in 1492 to the Catholic monarchs <a href="/wiki/Isabella_I_of_Castile" title="Isabella I of Castile">Queen Isabella I</a> of <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_Castile" title="Crown of Castile">Castile</a><sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[48]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_II_of_Aragon" title="Ferdinand II of Aragon">King Ferdinand II</a> of <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_Arag%C3%B3n" class="mw-redirect" title="Crown of Aragón">Aragon</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[49]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[50]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[51]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bataille_de_la_Rochelle.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Bataille_de_la_Rochelle.jpg/220px-Bataille_de_la_Rochelle.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="208" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Bataille_de_la_Rochelle.jpg/330px-Bataille_de_la_Rochelle.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Bataille_de_la_Rochelle.jpg/440px-Bataille_de_la_Rochelle.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2014" data-file-height="1907"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bataille_de_la_Rochelle.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_La_Rochelle" title="Battle of La Rochelle">Battle of La Rochelle</a>, 1372
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>From the mid 13th century, literature and philosophy started to flourish again in the Christian peninsular kingdoms, based on Roman and Gothic traditions. An important philosopher from this time is <a href="/wiki/Ramon_Llull" title="Ramon Llull">Ramon Llull</a>. <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Cresques" title="Abraham Cresques">Abraham Cresques</a> was a prominent Jewish cartographer. <a href="/wiki/Roman_law" title="Roman law">Roman law</a> and its institutions were the model for the legislators. The king <a href="/wiki/Alfonso_X_of_Castile" title="Alfonso X of Castile">Alfonso X of Castile</a> focused on strengthening this Roman and Gothic past, and also on linking the Iberian Christian kingdoms with the rest of medieval European <a href="/wiki/Christendom" title="Christendom">Christendom</a>. Alfonso worked for being elected emperor of the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Holy Roman Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a> and published the <a href="/wiki/Siete_Partidas" title="Siete Partidas">Siete Partidas</a> code. The <a href="/wiki/Toledo_School_of_Translators" title="Toledo School of Translators">Toledo School of Translators</a> is the name that commonly describes the group of scholars who worked together in the city of Toledo during the 12th and 13th centuries, to translate many of the philosophical and scientific works from <a href="/wiki/Classical_Arabic" title="Classical Arabic">Classical Arabic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">Ancient Greek</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Biblical_Hebrew" title="Biblical Hebrew">Ancient Hebrew</a>. </p>
      <p>The 13th century also witnessed the <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_Aragon" title="Crown of Aragon">Crown of Aragon</a>, centred in Spain's north east, expand its reach across islands in the Mediterranean, to <a href="/wiki/Sicily" title="Sicily">Sicily</a> and Naples.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[52]</a></sup> Around this time the universities of <a href="/wiki/University_of_Palencia" title="University of Palencia">Palencia</a> (1212/1263) and <a href="/wiki/University_of_Salamanca" title="University of Salamanca">Salamanca</a> (1218/1254) were established. The <a href="/wiki/Black_Death" title="Black Death">Black Death</a> of 1348 and 1349 devastated Spain.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[53]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Catalans and Aragonese offered themselves to the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Emperor" class="mw-redirect" title="Byzantine Emperor">Byzantine Emperor</a> <a href="/wiki/Andronicus_II_Palaeologus" class="mw-redirect" title="Andronicus II Palaeologus">Andronicus II Palaeologus</a> to <a href="/wiki/Catalan_campaign_in_Asia_Minor" title="Catalan campaign in Asia Minor">fight the Turks</a>. Having conquered these, they turned their arms against the Byzantines, who treacherously slew their leaders; but for this treachery, the Spaniards, under Bernard of Rocafort and Berenguer of Entenca, exacted the terrible penalty celebrated in history as "The Catalan Vengeance" and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Halmyros" title="Battle of Halmyros">seized</a> the <a href="/wiki/Frankish_Greece" class="mw-redirect" title="Frankish Greece">Frankish</a> <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Athens" title="Duchy of Athens">Duchy of Athens</a> (1311).<sup id="cite_ref-Spain_33-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Spain-33">[25]</a></sup> The royal line of Aragon became extinct with <a href="/wiki/Martin_the_Humane" class="mw-redirect" title="Martin the Humane">Martin the Humane</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Compromise_of_Caspe" title="Compromise of Caspe">Compromise of Caspe</a> gave the Crown to the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Trast%C3%A1mara" title="House of Trastámara">House of Trastámara</a>, already reigning in Castile. </p>
      <p>As in the rest of Europe during the Late Middle Ages, <a href="/wiki/Antisemitism_in_Spain" title="Antisemitism in Spain">Antisemitism</a> greatly increased during the 14th century in the Christian kingdoms (a key event in that regard was the Black Death, as Jews were accused of poisoning the waters).<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[54]</a></sup> There were mass killings in Aragon in the mid-14th century, and 12,000 Jews were killed in Toledo. In 1391, Christian mobs went from town to town throughout Castile and Aragon, killing an estimated 50,000 Jews.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[55]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[56]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[57]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[58]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[59]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[60]</a></sup> Women and children were sold as slaves to Muslims, and many synagogues were converted into churches. According to <a href="/wiki/Hasdai_Crescas" title="Hasdai Crescas">Hasdai Crescas</a>, about 70 Jewish communities were destroyed.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[61]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/St._Vincent_Ferrer" class="mw-redirect" title="St. Vincent Ferrer">St. Vincent Ferrer</a> converted innumerable Jews, among them the Rabbi Josuah Halorqui, who took the name of <a href="/wiki/Jer%C3%B3nimo_de_Santa_Fe" class="mw-redirect" title="Jerónimo de Santa Fe">Jerónimo de Santa Fe</a> and in his town converted many of his former coreligionists in the famous <a href="/wiki/Disputation_of_Tortosa" title="Disputation of Tortosa">Disputation of Tortosa</a> (1413–14). </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Spanish_Empire">Spanish Empire</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish Empire</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Emanuel_Gottlieb_Leutze_-_Columbus_Before_the_Queen.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Emanuel_Gottlieb_Leutze_-_Columbus_Before_the_Queen.JPG/220px-Emanuel_Gottlieb_Leutze_-_Columbus_Before_the_Queen.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="164" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Emanuel_Gottlieb_Leutze_-_Columbus_Before_the_Queen.JPG/330px-Emanuel_Gottlieb_Leutze_-_Columbus_Before_the_Queen.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Emanuel_Gottlieb_Leutze_-_Columbus_Before_the_Queen.JPG/440px-Emanuel_Gottlieb_Leutze_-_Columbus_Before_the_Queen.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1536" data-file-height="1147"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Emanuel_Gottlieb_Leutze_-_Columbus_Before_the_Queen.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Christopher_Columbus" title="Christopher Columbus">Christopher Columbus</a> meets <a href="/wiki/Isabella_I_of_Castile" title="Isabella I of Castile">Isabella I of Castile</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_II_of_Aragon" title="Ferdinand II of Aragon">Ferdinand II of Aragon</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Alc%C3%A1zar_de_los_Reyes_Cristianos" title="Alcázar de los Reyes Cristianos">Alcázar of Córdoba</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1469, the crowns of the Christian kingdoms of <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_Castile" title="Crown of Castile">Castile</a> and <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_Aragon" title="Crown of Aragon">Aragon</a> were united by the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Monarchs" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic Monarchs">marriage</a> of <a href="/wiki/Isabella_I_of_Castile" title="Isabella I of Castile">Isabella I of Castile</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_II_of_Aragon" title="Ferdinand II of Aragon">Ferdinand II of Aragon</a>. 1478 commenced the completion of the conquest of the <a href="/wiki/Canary_Islands" title="Canary Islands">Canary Islands</a> and in 1492, the combined forces of Castile and Aragon captured the <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Granada" title="Emirate of Granada">Emirate of Granada</a> from its last ruler <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_XII_of_Granada" title="Muhammad XII of Granada">Muhammad XII</a>, ending the last remnant of a <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Muslim_presence_in_the_Iberian_peninsula" class="mw-redirect" title="Timeline of the Muslim presence in the Iberian peninsula">781-year presence</a> of Islamic rule in Iberia. That same year, <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Spain" title="History of the Jews in Spain">Spain's Jews</a> were <a href="/wiki/Converso" title="Converso">ordered to convert</a> to <a href="/wiki/Catholicism" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholicism">Catholicism</a> or face <a href="/wiki/Alhambra_Decree" title="Alhambra Decree">expulsion</a> from Spanish territories during the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Inquisition" title="Spanish Inquisition">Spanish Inquisition</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[62]</a></sup> As many as 200,000 Jews were <a href="/wiki/Expulsion_of_Jews_from_Spain" title="Expulsion of Jews from Spain">expelled from Spain</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[63]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[64]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[65]</a></sup> This was followed by expulsions in <a href="/wiki/Expulsion_of_the_Jews_from_Sicily" title="Expulsion of the Jews from Sicily">1493 in Aragonese Sicily</a> and <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Jews_and_Muslims_by_Manuel_I_of_Portugal" title="Persecution of Jews and Muslims by Manuel I of Portugal">Portugal in 1497</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Granada" class="mw-redirect" title="Treaty of Granada">Treaty of Granada</a> guaranteed religious tolerance towards Muslims,<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[66]</a></sup> for a few years before Islam was outlawed in 1502 in the Kingdom of Castile and 1527 in the Kingdom of Aragon, leading to Spain's Muslim population becoming nominally Christian <a href="/wiki/Morisco" title="Morisco">Moriscos</a>. A few decades after the Morisco rebellion of Granada known as the <a href="/wiki/War_of_the_Alpujarras" class="mw-redirect" title="War of the Alpujarras">War of the Alpujarras</a>, a significant proportion of Spain's formerly-Muslim population was expelled, settling primarily in North Africa.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[l]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-cong_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cong-79">[67]</a></sup> From 1609 to 1614, over 300,000 Moriscos were sent on ships to North Africa and other locations, and, of this figure, around 50,000 died resisting the <a href="/wiki/Expulsion_of_the_Moriscos" title="Expulsion of the Moriscos">expulsion</a>, and 60,000 died on the journey.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[68]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[69]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[70]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The year 1492 also marked the arrival of <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Columbus" title="Christopher Columbus">Christopher Columbus</a> in the <a href="/wiki/New_World" title="New World">New World</a>, during a voyage funded by Isabella. Columbus's first voyage crossed the Atlantic and reached the Caribbean Islands, beginning the European exploration and conquest of the Americas, although Columbus remained convinced that he had reached the <a href="/wiki/Orient" title="Orient">Orient</a>. Large numbers of <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas" title="Indigenous peoples of the Americas">indigenous Americans</a> died in battle against the Spaniards during the conquest,<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[71]</a></sup> while others died from various other causes. Some scholars consider the initial period of the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="Spanish colonization of the Americas">Spanish conquest</a>— from Columbus's first landing in the Bahamas until the middle of the sixteenth century—as marking the most egregious case of <a href="/wiki/Genocide" title="Genocide">genocide</a> in the history of mankind.<sup id="cite_ref-Naimark_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Naimark-84">[72]</a></sup> The death toll may have reached some 70 million indigenous people (out of 80 million) in this period, as diseases such as smallpox, measles, influenza, and typhus, brought to the Americas by the conquest, decimated the pre-Columbian population.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENaimark201735_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENaimark201735-85">[73]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
