      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mountains_and_rivers">Mountains and rivers</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Valley_of_Ordesa,_Ordesa_y_Monte_Perdido_National_Park,_Spain.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Valley_of_Ordesa%2C_Ordesa_y_Monte_Perdido_National_Park%2C_Spain.jpg/220px-Valley_of_Ordesa%2C_Ordesa_y_Monte_Perdido_National_Park%2C_Spain.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Valley_of_Ordesa%2C_Ordesa_y_Monte_Perdido_National_Park%2C_Spain.jpg/330px-Valley_of_Ordesa%2C_Ordesa_y_Monte_Perdido_National_Park%2C_Spain.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Valley_of_Ordesa%2C_Ordesa_y_Monte_Perdido_National_Park%2C_Spain.jpg/440px-Valley_of_Ordesa%2C_Ordesa_y_Monte_Perdido_National_Park%2C_Spain.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5504" data-file-height="3096"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Valley_of_Ordesa,_Ordesa_y_Monte_Perdido_National_Park,_Spain.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Ordesa_y_Monte_Perdido_National_Park" title="Ordesa y Monte Perdido National Park">Ordesa y Monte Perdido National Park</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Pyrenees" title="Pyrenees">Pyrenees</a>, a <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Mainland Spain is a <a href="/wiki/Mountainous" class="mw-redirect" title="Mountainous">mountainous</a> country, dominated by high <a href="/wiki/Plateau" title="Plateau">plateaus</a> and mountain chains. After the Pyrenees, the main mountain ranges are the <a href="/wiki/Cantabrian_Mountains" title="Cantabrian Mountains">Cordillera Cantábrica</a> (Cantabrian Range), <a href="/wiki/Sistema_Ib%C3%A9rico" title="Sistema Ibérico">Sistema Ibérico</a> (Iberian System), <a href="/wiki/Sistema_Central" title="Sistema Central">Sistema Central</a> (Central System), <a href="/wiki/Montes_de_Toledo" title="Montes de Toledo">Montes de Toledo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Morena" title="Sierra Morena">Sierra Morena</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sistema_B%C3%A9tico" class="mw-redirect" title="Sistema Bético">Sistema Bético</a> (Baetic System) whose highest peak, the 3,478-metre-high (11,411-foot) <a href="/wiki/Mulhac%C3%A9n" title="Mulhacén">Mulhacén</a>, located in <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Nevada_(Spain)" title="Sierra Nevada (Spain)">Sierra Nevada</a>, is the highest elevation in the Iberian Peninsula. The highest point in Spain is the <a href="/wiki/Teide" title="Teide">Teide</a>, a 3,718-metre (12,198&nbsp;ft) active <a href="/wiki/Volcano" title="Volcano">volcano</a> in the Canary Islands. The <a href="/wiki/Meseta_Central" title="Meseta Central">Meseta Central</a> (often translated as "Inner Plateau") is a vast plateau in the heart of peninsular Spain. </p>
      <p>There are several major <a href="/wiki/Rivers_in_Spain" class="mw-redirect" title="Rivers in Spain">rivers in Spain</a> such as the <a href="/wiki/Tagus" title="Tagus">Tagus</a> (<i>Tajo</i>), <a href="/wiki/Ebro" title="Ebro">Ebro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guadiana_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Guadiana River">Guadiana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Douro" title="Douro">Douro</a> (<i>Duero</i>), <a href="/wiki/Guadalquivir" title="Guadalquivir">Guadalquivir</a>, <a href="/wiki/J%C3%BAcar_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Júcar River">Júcar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Segura" title="Segura">Segura</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turia_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Turia River">Turia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Minho_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Minho River">Minho</a> (<i>Miño</i>). <a href="/wiki/Alluvial_plain" title="Alluvial plain">Alluvial plains</a> are found along the coast, the largest of which is that of the Guadalquivir in <a href="/wiki/Andalusia" title="Andalusia">Andalusia</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Spain" title="Climate of Spain">Climate of Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Noriega_1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Noriega_1.jpg/220px-Noriega_1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="137" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Noriega_1.jpg/330px-Noriega_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Noriega_1.jpg/440px-Noriega_1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3796" data-file-height="2356"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Noriega_1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The coast north of the Cantabrian Mountains features an humid oceanic climate
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bolnuevo-sierra-moreras.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Bolnuevo-sierra-moreras.jpg/220px-Bolnuevo-sierra-moreras.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="164" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Bolnuevo-sierra-moreras.jpg/330px-Bolnuevo-sierra-moreras.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Bolnuevo-sierra-moreras.jpg/440px-Bolnuevo-sierra-moreras.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1044" data-file-height="777"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bolnuevo-sierra-moreras.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The southeasternmost end of the Iberian peninsula features an arid climate.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Three main climatic zones can be separated, according to geographical situation and <a href="/wiki/Orography" title="Orography">orographic</a> conditions:<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[121]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[122]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[123]</a></sup> </p> 
      <ul>
       <li>The <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">Mediterranean climate</a>, characterised by warm/hot and dry summers, is dominant in the peninsula. It has two varieties: <i>Csa</i> and <i>Csb</i> according to the <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a>. 
        <ul>
         <li>The <i>Csa</i> zone is associated to areas with hot summers. It is predominant in the Mediterranean and Southern Atlantic coast and inland throughout <a href="/wiki/Andalusia" title="Andalusia">Andalusia</a>, Extremadura and much, if not most, of the centre of the country. The <i>Csa</i> zone covers climatic zones with both relatively warm and cold winters which are considered extremely different to each other at a local level, reason for which Köppen classification is often eschewed within Spain. Local climatic maps generally divide the Mediterranean zone (which covers most of the country) between warm-winter and cold-winter zones, rather than according to summer temperatures.</li> 
         <li>The <i>Csb</i> zone has warm rather than hot summers, and extends to additional cool-winter areas not typically associated with a Mediterranean climate, such as much of central and northern-central of Spain (e.g. western <a href="/wiki/Castile_and_Le%C3%B3n" title="Castile and León">Castile–León</a>, northeastern <a href="/wiki/Castilla-La_Mancha" class="mw-redirect" title="Castilla-La Mancha">Castilla-La Mancha</a> and northern <a href="/wiki/Community_of_Madrid" title="Community of Madrid">Madrid</a>) and into much rainier areas (notably <a href="/wiki/Galicia_(Spain)" title="Galicia (Spain)">Galicia</a>). Note areas with relatively high rainfall such as Galicia are not considered Mediterranean under local classifications, but classed as oceanic.</li>
        </ul></li> 
       <li>The <a href="/wiki/Semi-arid_climate" title="Semi-arid climate">semi-arid climate</a> (<i>BSk</i>, <i>BSh</i>), is predominant in the southeastern quarter of the country, but is also widespread in other areas of Spain. It covers most of the <a href="/wiki/Region_of_Murcia" title="Region of Murcia">Region of Murcia</a>, southern <a href="/wiki/Valencian_Community" title="Valencian Community">Valencia</a> and eastern Andalusia, where true hot desert climates also exist. Further to the north, it is predominant in the upper and mid reaches of the <a href="/wiki/Ebro" title="Ebro">Ebro</a> valley, which crosses southern <a href="/wiki/Navarre" title="Navarre">Navarre</a>, central Aragon and western Catalonia. It also is found in Madrid, Extremadura, Castilla-La Mancha, and some locations of western Andalusia. The dry season extends beyond the summer and average temperature depends on altitude and latitude.</li> 
       <li>The <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic climate</a> (<i>Cfb</i>), located in the northern quarter of the country, especially in the Atlantic region (<a href="/wiki/Basque_Country_(autonomous_community)" title="Basque Country (autonomous community)">Basque Country</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cantabria" title="Cantabria">Cantabria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Asturias" title="Asturias">Asturias</a>, and partly Galicia and Castile–León). Additionally it is also found in northern Navarre, in most highlands areas along the <a href="/wiki/Sistema_Ib%C3%A9rico" title="Sistema Ibérico">Iberian System</a> and in the <a href="/wiki/Pyrenees" title="Pyrenees">Pyrenean</a> valleys, where a humid subtropical variant (<i>Cfa</i>) also occurs. Winter and summer temperatures are influenced by the ocean, and have no seasonal drought.</li>
      </ul> 
      <p>Apart from these main types, other sub-types can be found, like the <a href="/wiki/Alpine_climate" title="Alpine climate">alpine climate</a> in areas with very high altitude, the <a href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate" title="Humid subtropical climate">humid subtropical climate</a> in areas of northeastern Spain and the <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">continental climates</a> (<i>Dfc</i>, <i>Dfb</i> / <i>Dsc</i>, <i>Dsb</i>) in the <a href="/wiki/Pyrenees" title="Pyrenees">Pyrenees</a> as well as parts of the <a href="/wiki/Cordillera_Cant%C3%A1brica" class="mw-redirect" title="Cordillera Cantábrica">Cantabrian Range</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Sistema_Central" title="Sistema Central">Central System</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Nevada_(Spain)" title="Sierra Nevada (Spain)">Sierra Nevada</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sistema_Ib%C3%A9rico" title="Sistema Ibérico">Iberian System</a>, and a typical <a href="/wiki/Desert_climate" title="Desert climate">desert climate</a> (<i>BWk</i>, <i>BWh</i>) in the zone of Almería, Murcia and eastern <a href="/wiki/Canary_Islands" title="Canary Islands">Canary Islands</a>. Low-lying areas of the Canary Islands average above 18.0&nbsp;°C (64.4&nbsp;°F) during their coldest month, thus having a <a href="/wiki/Tropical_climate" title="Tropical climate">tropical climate</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fauna_and_flora">Fauna and flora</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Iberian_Wolf_AdF_001.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Iberian_Wolf_AdF_001.jpg/220px-Iberian_Wolf_AdF_001.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Iberian_Wolf_AdF_001.jpg/330px-Iberian_Wolf_AdF_001.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Iberian_Wolf_AdF_001.jpg/440px-Iberian_Wolf_AdF_001.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="1996"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Iberian_Wolf_AdF_001.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Iberian_wolf" title="Iberian wolf">Iberian wolf</a> in <a href="/wiki/Castile_and_Leon" class="mw-redirect" title="Castile and Leon">Castile and Leon</a>. The region has the 25% of the land covered by <a href="/wiki/Natura_2000" title="Natura 2000">Natura 2000</a> protected natural spaces.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Spain" title="Wildlife of Spain">Wildlife of Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Fauna" title="Fauna">fauna</a> presents a wide diversity that is due in large part to the geographical position of the Iberian peninsula between the Atlantic and the Mediterranean and between Africa and <a href="/wiki/Eurasia" title="Eurasia">Eurasia</a>, and the great diversity of habitats and <a href="/wiki/Biotopes" class="mw-redirect" title="Biotopes">biotopes</a>, the result of a considerable variety of climates and well differentiated regions. </p>
      <p>The vegetation of Spain is varied due to several factors including the diversity of the terrain, the climate and <a href="/wiki/Latitude" title="Latitude">latitude</a>. Spain includes different <a href="/wiki/Phytogeographic" class="mw-redirect" title="Phytogeographic">phytogeographic</a> regions, each with its own floral characteristics resulting largely from the interaction of climate, topography, soil type and fire, and <a href="/wiki/Biotic_component" title="Biotic component">biotic</a> factors. The country had a 2019 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 4.23/10, ranking it 130th globally out of 172 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-136">[124]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Spain" title="Politics of Spain">Politics of Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Constitution_of_1978" class="mw-redirect" title="Spanish Constitution of 1978">Spanish Constitution of 1978</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The constitutional history of Spain dates back to the constitution of 1812. In June 1976, Spain's new King <a href="/wiki/Juan_Carlos" class="mw-redirect" title="Juan Carlos">Juan Carlos</a> dismissed <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Arias_Navarro" title="Carlos Arias Navarro">Carlos Arias Navarro</a> and appointed the reformer <a href="/wiki/Adolfo_Su%C3%A1rez" title="Adolfo Suárez">Adolfo Suárez</a> as Prime Minister.<sup id="cite_ref-From_Dictatorship_to_Democracy_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-From_Dictatorship_to_Democracy-137">[125]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Spain's_fast-living_king_turns_70_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Spain's_fast-living_king_turns_70-138">[126]</a></sup> The resulting <a href="/wiki/1977_Spanish_general_election" title="1977 Spanish general election">general election in 1977</a> convened the <i><a href="/wiki/Constituent_Cortes" title="Constituent Cortes">Constituent Cortes</a></i> (the Spanish Parliament, in its capacity as a constitutional assembly) for the purpose of drafting and approving the constitution of 1978.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[127]</a></sup> After a national referendum on 6 December 1978, 88% of voters approved of the new constitution – a culmination of the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_transition_to_democracy" title="Spanish transition to democracy">Spanish transition to democracy</a>. </p>
      <p>As a result, Spain is now composed of 17 <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_communities_of_Spain" title="Autonomous communities of Spain">autonomous communities</a> and two <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_communities_of_Spain#Autonomous_cities_and_&quot;plazas_de_soberanía&quot;" title="Autonomous communities of Spain">autonomous cities</a> with varying degrees of autonomy thanks to its Constitution, which nevertheless explicitly states the indivisible unity of the Spanish nation. The constitution also specifies that Spain has no state religion and that all are free to practice and believe as they wish. </p>
      <p>The Spanish administration approved the <i>Gender Equality Act</i> in 2007 aimed at furthering <a href="/wiki/Gender_equality" title="Gender equality">equality between genders</a> in Spanish political and economic life.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[128]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Inter-Parliamentary_Union" title="Inter-Parliamentary Union">Inter-Parliamentary Union</a> data as of 1 September 2018, 137 of the 350 members of the Congress were women (39.1%), while in the Senate, there were 101 women out of 266 (39.9%), placing Spain 16th on their list of countries ranked by proportion of women in the <a href="/wiki/Lower_House" class="mw-redirect" title="Lower House">lower</a> (or <a href="/wiki/Unicameral" class="mw-redirect" title="Unicameral">single</a>) House.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[129]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Gender_Empowerment_Measure" title="Gender Empowerment Measure">Gender Empowerment Measure</a> of Spain in the United Nations <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Report" title="Human Development Report">Human Development Report</a> is 0.794, 12th in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[130]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Conmemoraci%C3%B3n_del_40_Aniversario_de_la_Constituci%C3%B3n_Espa%C3%B1ola_05.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Conmemoraci%C3%B3n_del_40_Aniversario_de_la_Constituci%C3%B3n_Espa%C3%B1ola_05.jpg/220px-Conmemoraci%C3%B3n_del_40_Aniversario_de_la_Constituci%C3%B3n_Espa%C3%B1ola_05.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Conmemoraci%C3%B3n_del_40_Aniversario_de_la_Constituci%C3%B3n_Espa%C3%B1ola_05.jpg/330px-Conmemoraci%C3%B3n_del_40_Aniversario_de_la_Constituci%C3%B3n_Espa%C3%B1ola_05.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Conmemoraci%C3%B3n_del_40_Aniversario_de_la_Constituci%C3%B3n_Espa%C3%B1ola_05.jpg/440px-Conmemoraci%C3%B3n_del_40_Aniversario_de_la_Constituci%C3%B3n_Espa%C3%B1ola_05.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="1333"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Conmemoraci%C3%B3n_del_40_Aniversario_de_la_Constituci%C3%B3n_Espa%C3%B1ola_05.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Deputies" title="Congress of Deputies">Congress of Deputies</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Spain is a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a>, with a hereditary monarch and a <a href="/wiki/Bicameral_parliament" class="mw-redirect" title="Bicameral parliament">bicameral parliament</a>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Cortes_Generales" title="Cortes Generales">Cortes Generales</a></i> (General Courts).<sup id="cite_ref-Shelley2015_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Shelley2015-143">[131]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Legislative_branch" class="mw-redirect" title="Legislative branch">legislative branch</a> is made up of the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Deputies" title="Congress of Deputies">Congress of Deputies</a> (<i>Congreso de los Diputados</i>), a lower house with 350 members, elected by popular vote on block lists by proportional representation to serve four-year terms, and the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Senate" class="mw-redirect" title="Spanish Senate">Senate</a> (<i>Senado</i>), an upper house with 259 seats of which 208 are directly elected by popular vote, using a <a href="/wiki/Limited_voting" title="Limited voting">limited voting</a> method, and the other 51 appointed by the regional legislatures to also serve four-year terms. </p>
      <p>The executive branch consists of a <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_of_Spain" class="mw-redirect" title="Council of Ministers of Spain">Council of Ministers</a> presided over by the Prime Minister, who is <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Spain#Royal_Nomination,_Congressional_Confirmation" title="Prime Minister of Spain">nominated as candidate</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_Spain" title="Monarchy of Spain">monarch</a> after holding consultations with representatives from the different parliamentary groups, voted in by the members of the lower house during an investiture session and then formally appointed by the monarch. </p> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:151px;max-width:151px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:190px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Felipe_VI_-_14.07.11-Escuela_Marina-1-San_Fernando-edit3.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Felipe_VI_-_14.07.11-Escuela_Marina-1-San_Fernando-edit3.jpg/149px-Felipe_VI_-_14.07.11-Escuela_Marina-1-San_Fernando-edit3.jpg" decoding="async" width="149" height="191" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Felipe_VI_-_14.07.11-Escuela_Marina-1-San_Fernando-edit3.jpg/224px-Felipe_VI_-_14.07.11-Escuela_Marina-1-San_Fernando-edit3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Felipe_VI_-_14.07.11-Escuela_Marina-1-San_Fernando-edit3.jpg/298px-Felipe_VI_-_14.07.11-Escuela_Marina-1-San_Fernando-edit3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="402" data-file-height="515"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           King <a href="/wiki/Felipe_VI_of_Spain" class="mw-redirect" title="Felipe VI of Spain">Philip VI</a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:137px;max-width:137px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:190px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Pedro_S%C3%A1nchez_in_2020.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Pedro_S%C3%A1nchez_in_2020.jpg/135px-Pedro_S%C3%A1nchez_in_2020.jpg" decoding="async" width="135" height="190" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Pedro_S%C3%A1nchez_in_2020.jpg/203px-Pedro_S%C3%A1nchez_in_2020.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Pedro_S%C3%A1nchez_in_2020.jpg/270px-Pedro_S%C3%A1nchez_in_2020.jpg 2x" data-file-width="555" data-file-height="780"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Spain" title="Prime Minister of Spain">PM</a> <a href="/wiki/Pedro_S%C3%A1nchez_(politician)" class="mw-redirect" title="Pedro Sánchez (politician)">Pedro Sánchez</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <ul>
       <li><b>Head of State</b> (King) 
        <ul>
         <li><a href="/wiki/Felipe_VI_of_Spain" class="mw-redirect" title="Felipe VI of Spain">Felipe VI</a>, since 19 June 2014</li>
        </ul></li> 
       <li><b>Government</b></li>
      </ul> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Spain" title="Government of Spain">Government of Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Spanish_government_departments" title="Spanish government departments">Spanish government departments</a>
      </div> 
      <ul>
       <li>
        <ul>
         <li><a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Spain" title="Prime Minister of Spain">Prime Minister</a> (head of government) or "President of the Government" (<i>Presidente del Gobierno</i>): <a href="/wiki/Pedro_S%C3%A1nchez_P%C3%A9rez-Castej%C3%B3n" class="mw-redirect" title="Pedro Sánchez Pérez-Castejón">Pedro Sánchez Pérez-Castejón</a>, elected 1 June 2018.</li> 
         <li>Deputy prime ministers (designated by the Prime Minister): Currently <a href="/wiki/Carmen_Calvo_Poyato" class="mw-redirect" title="Carmen Calvo Poyato">Carmen Calvo Poyato</a> (1st), <a href="/wiki/Pablo_Iglesias_Turri%C3%B3n" title="Pablo Iglesias Turrión">Pablo Iglesias Turrión</a> (2nd), <a href="/wiki/Nadia_Calvi%C3%B1o_Santamar%C3%ADa" class="mw-redirect" title="Nadia Calviño Santamaría">Nadia Calviño Santamaría</a> (3rd), <a href="/wiki/Teresa_Ribera_Rodr%C3%ADguez" class="mw-redirect" title="Teresa Ribera Rodríguez">Teresa Ribera Rodríguez</a> (4th).</li> 
         <li>Ministers (designated by the Prime Minister).</li>
        </ul></li>
      </ul> 
      <p>The Prime Minister, deputy prime ministers and the rest of ministers convene at the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_of_Spain" class="mw-redirect" title="Council of Ministers of Spain">Council of Ministers</a>. </p>
      <p>Spain is organisationally structured as a so-called <i>Estado de las Autonomías</i> ("State of Autonomies"); it is one of the most <a href="/wiki/Decentralised" class="mw-redirect" title="Decentralised">decentralised</a> countries in Europe, along with Switzerland, Germany and Belgium;<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[132]</a></sup> for example, all autonomous communities have their own elected parliaments, governments, <a href="/wiki/Public_Administration_of_Spain" title="Public Administration of Spain">public administrations</a>, budgets, and resources. Health and education systems among others are managed by the Spanish communities, and in addition, the Basque Country and Navarre also manage their own public finances based on <a href="/wiki/Fuero" title="Fuero">foral</a> provisions. In Catalonia, the Basque Country, Navarre and the Canary Islands, a full-fledged autonomous police corps replaces some of the State police functions (see <i><a href="/wiki/Mossos_d%27Esquadra" title="Mossos d'Esquadra">Mossos d'Esquadra</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Ertzaintza" title="Ertzaintza">Ertzaintza</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Polic%C3%ADa_Foral" title="Policía Foral">Policía Foral</a>/Foruzaingoa</i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Polic%C3%ADa_Canaria" title="Policía Canaria">Policía Canaria</a></i>). </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Spain" title="Foreign relations of Spain">Foreign relations of Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Palau_Reial_Pedralbes_(Barcelona).JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Palau_Reial_Pedralbes_%28Barcelona%29.JPG/220px-Palau_Reial_Pedralbes_%28Barcelona%29.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="106" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Palau_Reial_Pedralbes_%28Barcelona%29.JPG/330px-Palau_Reial_Pedralbes_%28Barcelona%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Palau_Reial_Pedralbes_%28Barcelona%29.JPG/440px-Palau_Reial_Pedralbes_%28Barcelona%29.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4867" data-file-height="2343"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Palau_Reial_Pedralbes_(Barcelona).JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Palau_Reial_de_Pedralbes" title="Palau Reial de Pedralbes">Palau Reial de Pedralbes</a> in Barcelona, headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/Union_for_the_Mediterranean" title="Union for the Mediterranean">Union for the Mediterranean</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>After the return of democracy following the death of <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Franco" title="Francisco Franco">Franco</a> in 1975, Spain's <a href="/wiki/Foreign_policy" title="Foreign policy">foreign policy</a> priorities were to break out of the diplomatic isolation of the <a href="/wiki/Spain_under_Franco" class="mw-redirect" title="Spain under Franco">Franco years</a> and expand <a href="/wiki/Diplomatic_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="Diplomatic relations">diplomatic relations</a>, enter the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Community</a>, and define security relations with the West. </p>
      <p>As a member of <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> since 1982, Spain has established itself as a participant in multilateral international security activities. Spain's EU membership represents an important part of its foreign policy. Even on many international issues beyond western Europe, Spain prefers to coordinate its efforts with its EU partners through the European political co-operation mechanisms.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Vagueness" title="Wikipedia:Vagueness"><span title="This information is too vague. (March 2015)">vague</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Spain has maintained its special relations with <a href="/wiki/Hispanic_America" title="Hispanic America">Hispanic America</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>. Its policy emphasises the concept of an <a href="/wiki/Ibero-America" title="Ibero-America">Ibero-American</a> community, essentially the renewal of the concept of <i>"<a href="/wiki/Hispanidad" title="Hispanidad">Hispanidad</a>"</i> or <i>"<a href="/wiki/Hispanism" title="Hispanism">Hispanismo</a>"</i>, as it is often referred to in English, which has sought to link the Iberian Peninsula with Hispanic America through language, commerce, history and culture. It is fundamentally "based on shared values and the recovery of democracy."<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[133]</a></sup> </p> 
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Territorial disputes
       </dt>
      </dl> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Disputed_status_of_Gibraltar" class="mw-redirect" title="Disputed status of Gibraltar">Spain claims Gibraltar</a>, a 6-square-kilometre (2.3&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) <a href="/wiki/British_overseas_territories" class="mw-redirect" title="British overseas territories">Overseas Territory of the United Kingdom</a> in the southernmost part of the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a>. Then a Spanish town, it was conquered by an Anglo-Dutch force in 1704 during the <a href="/wiki/War_of_the_Spanish_Succession" title="War of the Spanish Succession">War of the Spanish Succession</a> on behalf of <a href="/wiki/Charles_VI,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Charles VI, Holy Roman Emperor">Archduke Charles</a>, pretender to the Spanish throne. </p>
      <p>The legal situation concerning Gibraltar was settled in 1713 by the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Utrecht" class="mw-redirect" title="Treaty of Utrecht">Treaty of Utrecht</a>, in which Spain ceded the territory in perpetuity to the British Crown<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[134]</a></sup> stating that, should the British abandon this post, it would be offered to Spain first. Since the 1940s Spain has called for the return of Gibraltar. The overwhelming majority of <a href="/wiki/Gibraltarians" title="Gibraltarians">Gibraltarians</a> strongly oppose this, along with any proposal of shared sovereignty.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[135]</a></sup> UN resolutions call on the United Kingdom and Spain to reach an agreement over the status of Gibraltar.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[136]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[137]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Gibraltar_10000m.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Gibraltar_10000m.jpg/220px-Gibraltar_10000m.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Gibraltar_10000m.jpg/330px-Gibraltar_10000m.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Gibraltar_10000m.jpg/440px-Gibraltar_10000m.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5630" data-file-height="3753"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Gibraltar_10000m.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Aerial view showing the <a href="/wiki/Rock_of_Gibraltar" title="Rock of Gibraltar">Rock of Gibraltar</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Isthmus_of_Gibraltar" class="mw-redirect" title="Isthmus of Gibraltar">isthmus of Gibraltar</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Gibraltar" title="Bay of Gibraltar">Bay of Gibraltar</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Spanish claim makes a distinction between the <a href="/wiki/Disputed_status_of_the_isthmus_between_Gibraltar_and_Spain" title="Disputed status of the isthmus between Gibraltar and Spain">isthmus</a> that connects the Rock to the Spanish mainland on the one hand, and the Rock and city of Gibraltar on the other. While the Rock and city were ceded by the Treaty of Utrecht, Spain asserts that the "occupation of the isthmus is illegal and against the principles of <a href="/wiki/International_Law" class="mw-redirect" title="International Law">International Law</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[138]</a></sup> The United Kingdom relies on <i>de facto</i> arguments of possession by <a href="/wiki/Prescription_(sovereignty_transfer)" title="Prescription (sovereignty transfer)">prescription</a> in relation to the isthmus,<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[139]</a></sup> as there has been "continuous possession [of the isthmus] over a long period".<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[140]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Another claim by Spain is about the <a href="/wiki/Savage_Islands" title="Savage Islands">Savage Islands</a>, part of <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portugal</a>. In clash with the Portuguese position, Spain claims that they are rocks rather than islands, and therefore Spain does not accept any extension of the Portuguese <a href="/wiki/Exclusive_Economic_Zone" class="mw-redirect" title="Exclusive Economic Zone">Exclusive Economic Zone</a> (200 nautical miles) generated by the islands, while acknowledging the <i>Selvagens</i> having <a href="/wiki/Territorial_waters" title="Territorial waters">territorial waters</a> (12 nautical miles). On 5 July 2013, Spain sent a letter to the UN expressing these views.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[141]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[142]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Spain claims the sovereignty over the <a href="/wiki/Perejil_Island" title="Perejil Island">Perejil Island</a>, a small, uninhabited rocky <a href="/wiki/Islet" title="Islet">islet</a> located in the South shore of the <a href="/wiki/Strait_of_Gibraltar" title="Strait of Gibraltar">Strait of Gibraltar</a>. The island lies 250 metres (820&nbsp;ft) just off the coast of Morocco, 8 kilometres (5.0&nbsp;mi) from <a href="/wiki/Ceuta" title="Ceuta">Ceuta</a> and 13.5 kilometres (8.4&nbsp;mi) from mainland Spain. Its sovereignty is disputed between Spain and Morocco. It was the subject of an armed incident between the two countries in 2002. The incident ended when both countries agreed to return to the status quo ante which existed prior to the Moroccan occupation of the island. The islet is now deserted and without any sign of sovereignty. </p>
      <p>Besides the Perejil Island, the Spanish-held territories claimed by other countries are two: Morocco claims the Spanish cities of Ceuta and <a href="/wiki/Melilla" title="Melilla">Melilla</a> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Plazas_de_soberan%C3%ADa" title="Plazas de soberanía">plazas de soberanía</a></i> islets off the northern coast of Africa. Portugal does not recognise Spain's sovereignty over the territory of <a href="/wiki/Olivenza" title="Olivenza">Olivenza</a> which was annexed by Spain in 1801 after the <a href="/wiki/War_of_the_Oranges" title="War of the Oranges">War of the Oranges</a>. Portugal stance has been the territory being <i>de iure</i> Portuguese territory and <i>de facto</i> Spanish.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[143]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Armed_Forces" title="Spanish Armed Forces">Spanish Armed Forces</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:F-102_Almirante_Juan_de_Borbon_CSSQT.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/F-102_Almirante_Juan_de_Borbon_CSSQT.jpg/220px-F-102_Almirante_Juan_de_Borbon_CSSQT.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/F-102_Almirante_Juan_de_Borbon_CSSQT.jpg/330px-F-102_Almirante_Juan_de_Borbon_CSSQT.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/F-102_Almirante_Juan_de_Borbon_CSSQT.jpg/440px-F-102_Almirante_Juan_de_Borbon_CSSQT.jpg 2x" data-file-width="720" data-file-height="480"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:F-102_Almirante_Juan_de_Borbon_CSSQT.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Spanish_frigate_Almirante_Juan_de_Borb%C3%B3n" title="Spanish frigate Almirante Juan de Borbón">Almirante Juan de Borbón (F-102)</a>, a Spanish navy's <a href="/wiki/%C3%81lvaro_de_Baz%C3%A1n-class_frigate" title="Álvaro de Bazán-class frigate">F100 class</a> frigate incorporating the <a href="/wiki/Aegis_Combat_System" title="Aegis Combat System">Aegis Combat System</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The armed forces of Spain are known as the Spanish Armed Forces (<i>Fuerzas Armadas Españolas</i>). Their <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">Commander-in-chief</a> is the <a href="/wiki/King_of_Spain" class="mw-redirect" title="King of Spain">King of Spain</a>, <a href="/wiki/Felipe_VI_of_Spain" class="mw-redirect" title="Felipe VI of Spain">Felipe VI</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[144]</a></sup> The next military authorities in line are the Prime Minister and the Minister of Defence. The fourth military authority of the State is the <a href="/wiki/Chief_of_the_Defence_Staff_(Spain)" title="Chief of the Defence Staff (Spain)">Chief of the Defence Staff</a> (JEMAD).<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[145]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Defence_Staff_(Spain)" title="Defence Staff (Spain)">Defence Staff</a> (<i>Estado Mayor de la Defensa</i>) assists the JEMAD as auxiliary body. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Armed_Forces" title="Spanish Armed Forces">Spanish Armed Forces</a> are divided into three branches:<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[146]</a></sup> </p> 
      <ul>
       <li><a href="/wiki/Spanish_Army" title="Spanish Army">Army (<i>Ejército de Tierra</i>)</a></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Spanish_Navy" title="Spanish Navy">Navy (<i>Armada</i>)</a></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Spanish_Air_Force" title="Spanish Air Force">Air Force (<i>Ejército del Aire</i>)</a></li>
      </ul> 
      <p>Military conscription was suppressed in 2001.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[147]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">Human rights</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Spain" title="Human rights in Spain">Human rights in Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Spain" title="LGBT rights in Spain">LGBT rights in Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Europride_2007_Madrid.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Europride_2007_Madrid.JPG/220px-Europride_2007_Madrid.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Europride_2007_Madrid.JPG/330px-Europride_2007_Madrid.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Europride_2007_Madrid.JPG/440px-Europride_2007_Madrid.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3264" data-file-height="2448"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Europride_2007_Madrid.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Europride" class="mw-redirect" title="Europride">Europride</a> in Madrid. In 2017 a summit on LGBTI human rights took place at the same time as <a href="/wiki/World_Pride" class="mw-redirect" title="World Pride">World Pride</a> celebrations.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[148]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Constitution_of_1978" class="mw-redirect" title="Spanish Constitution of 1978">Spanish Constitution of 1978</a> "protect all Spaniards and all the peoples of Spain in the exercise of human rights, their cultures and traditions, languages and institutions".<sup id="cite_ref-Constitucion1978.2_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitucion1978.2-161">[149]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a> (AI), government investigations of alleged police abuses are often lengthy and punishments were light.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[150]</a></sup> Violence against women was a problem, which the Government took steps to address.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[151]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[152]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Spain provides one of the highest degrees of liberty in the world for its <a href="/wiki/LGBT" title="LGBT">LGBT</a> community. Among the countries studied by <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew Research Center</a> in 2013, Spain is rated first in acceptance of homosexuality, with 88% of those surveyed saying that homosexuality should be accepted.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[153]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Political_divisions_of_Spain" title="Political divisions of Spain">Political divisions of Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The Spanish State is divided into 17 autonomous communities and 2 autonomous cities, both groups being the highest or first-order administrative division in the country. Autonomous communities are divided into provinces, of which there are 50 in total, and in turn, provinces are divided into municipalities. In Catalonia, two additional divisions exist, the <i>comarques</i> (sing. <i>comarca</i>) and the <i>vegueries</i> (sing. <i>vegueria</i>) both of which have administrative powers; <i>comarques</i> being aggregations of municipalities, and the <i>vegueries</i> being aggregations of <i>comarques</i>. The concept of a <i>comarca</i> exists in all autonomous communities, however, unlike Catalonia, these are merely historical or geographical subdivisions. </p>
