       </div> 
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:178px; top:50.4px">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_La_Rioja_(with_coat_of_arms).svg" class="image"><img alt="Flag of La Rioja (with coat of arms).svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Flag_of_La_Rioja_%28with_coat_of_arms%29.svg/25px-Flag_of_La_Rioja_%28with_coat_of_arms%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="25" height="17" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Flag_of_La_Rioja_%28with_coat_of_arms%29.svg/38px-Flag_of_La_Rioja_%28with_coat_of_arms%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Flag_of_La_Rioja_%28with_coat_of_arms%29.svg/50px-Flag_of_La_Rioja_%28with_coat_of_arms%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="500"></a>
       </div> 
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:187.6px; top:312px">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Melilla.svg" class="image"><img alt="Flag of Melilla.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Flag_of_Melilla.svg/25px-Flag_of_Melilla.svg.png" decoding="async" width="25" height="17" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Flag_of_Melilla.svg/38px-Flag_of_Melilla.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Flag_of_Melilla.svg/50px-Flag_of_Melilla.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="500"></a>
       </div> 
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:109px; top:296px">
        <i><a href="/wiki/Gibraltar" title="Gibraltar"><span style="color: #48A3B5;">Gibraltar (UK)</span></a></i>
       </div> 
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:114px; top:308px">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_Ceuta.svg" class="image"><img alt="Flag Ceuta.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Flag_Ceuta.svg/25px-Flag_Ceuta.svg.png" decoding="async" width="25" height="17" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Flag_Ceuta.svg/38px-Flag_Ceuta.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Flag_Ceuta.svg/50px-Flag_Ceuta.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="500"></a>
       </div> 
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:302px; top:72px">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Catalonia.svg" class="image"><img alt="Flag of Catalonia.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Flag_of_Catalonia.svg/25px-Flag_of_Catalonia.svg.png" decoding="async" width="25" height="17" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Flag_of_Catalonia.svg/38px-Flag_of_Catalonia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Flag_of_Catalonia.svg/50px-Flag_of_Catalonia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="810" data-file-height="540"></a>
       </div> 
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:138px; top:22.8px">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Cantabria.svg" class="image"><img alt="Flag of Cantabria.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Flag_of_Cantabria.svg/25px-Flag_of_Cantabria.svg.png" decoding="async" width="25" height="17" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Flag_of_Cantabria.svg/38px-Flag_of_Cantabria.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Flag_of_Cantabria.svg/50px-Flag_of_Cantabria.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="500"></a>
       </div> 
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:178px; top:24px">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_the_Basque_Country.svg" class="image"><img alt="Flag of the Basque Country.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Flag_of_the_Basque_Country.svg/25px-Flag_of_the_Basque_Country.svg.png" decoding="async" width="25" height="14" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Flag_of_the_Basque_Country.svg/38px-Flag_of_the_Basque_Country.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Flag_of_the_Basque_Country.svg/50px-Flag_of_the_Basque_Country.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="560"></a>
       </div> 
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:26px; top:36px">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Galicia.svg" class="image"><img alt="Flag of Galicia.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Flag_of_Galicia.svg/25px-Flag_of_Galicia.svg.png" decoding="async" width="25" height="17" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Flag_of_Galicia.svg/38px-Flag_of_Galicia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Flag_of_Galicia.svg/50px-Flag_of_Galicia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="400"></a>
       </div> 
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:72px; top:176px">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Extremadura_(with_coat_of_arms).svg" class="image"><img alt="Flag of Extremadura with COA.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Flag_of_Extremadura_%28with_coat_of_arms%29.svg/25px-Flag_of_Extremadura_%28with_coat_of_arms%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="25" height="17" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Flag_of_Extremadura_%28with_coat_of_arms%29.svg/38px-Flag_of_Extremadura_%28with_coat_of_arms%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Flag_of_Extremadura_%28with_coat_of_arms%29.svg/50px-Flag_of_Extremadura_%28with_coat_of_arms%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="500"></a>
       </div> 
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:206px; top:40px">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bandera_de_Navarra.svg" class="image"><img alt="Bandera de Navarra.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Bandera_de_Navarra.svg/25px-Bandera_de_Navarra.svg.png" decoding="async" width="25" height="17" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Bandera_de_Navarra.svg/38px-Bandera_de_Navarra.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Bandera_de_Navarra.svg/50px-Bandera_de_Navarra.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="500"></a>
       </div> 
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:80px; top:12.8px">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Asturias.svg" class="image"><img alt="Flag of Asturias.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Flag_of_Asturias.svg/25px-Flag_of_Asturias.svg.png" decoding="async" width="25" height="17" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Flag_of_Asturias.svg/38px-Flag_of_Asturias.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Flag_of_Asturias.svg/50px-Flag_of_Asturias.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600"></a>
       </div> 
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:318px; top:312px">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_the_Canary_Islands.svg" class="image"><img alt="Flag of the Canary Islands.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Flag_of_the_Canary_Islands.svg/25px-Flag_of_the_Canary_Islands.svg.png" decoding="async" width="25" height="17" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Flag_of_the_Canary_Islands.svg/38px-Flag_of_the_Canary_Islands.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Flag_of_the_Canary_Islands.svg/50px-Flag_of_the_Canary_Islands.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="400"></a>
       </div> 
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:211px; top:228px">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_the_Region_of_Murcia.svg" class="image"><img alt="Flag of the Region of Murcia.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Flag_of_the_Region_of_Murcia.svg/25px-Flag_of_the_Region_of_Murcia.svg.png" decoding="async" width="25" height="17" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Flag_of_the_Region_of_Murcia.svg/38px-Flag_of_the_Region_of_Murcia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Flag_of_the_Region_of_Murcia.svg/50px-Flag_of_the_Region_of_Murcia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="500"></a>
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>Spain's autonomous communities are the first level administrative divisions of the country. They were created after the current constitution came into effect (in 1978) in recognition of the right to self-government of the "<a href="/wiki/Nationalities_and_regions_of_Spain" title="Nationalities and regions of Spain"><i>nationalities</i> and regions of Spain</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[154]</a></sup> The autonomous communities were to comprise adjacent provinces with common historical, cultural, and economic traits. This territorial organisation, based on <a href="/wiki/Devolution" title="Devolution">devolution</a>, is known in Spain as the "State of Autonomies". </p>
      <p>The basic institutional law of each autonomous community is the <a href="/wiki/Statute_of_Autonomy" title="Statute of Autonomy">Statute of Autonomy</a>. The Statutes of Autonomy establish the name of the community according to its historical and contemporary identity, the limits of its territories, the name and organisation of the institutions of government and the rights they enjoy according to the constitution.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[155]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The governments of all autonomous communities must be based on a division of powers and comprise </p> 
      <ul>
       <li>a legislative assembly whose members must be elected by <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">universal suffrage</a> according to the system of <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">proportional representation</a> and in which all areas that integrate the territory are fairly represented;</li> 
       <li>a government council, with executive and administrative functions headed by a president, elected by the Legislative Assembly and nominated by the <a href="/wiki/King_of_Spain" class="mw-redirect" title="King of Spain">King of Spain</a>;</li> 
       <li>a supreme court, under the supreme court of Spain, which heads the judiciary in the autonomous community.</li>
      </ul> 
      <p>Catalonia, Galicia and the Basque Country, which identified themselves as <i>nationalities</i>, were granted self-government through a rapid process. Andalusia also took that denomination in its first Statute of Autonomy, even though it followed the longer process stipulated in the constitution for the rest of the country. Progressively, other communities in revisions to their Statutes of Autonomy have also taken that denomination in accordance to their historical and modern identities, such as the Valencian Community,<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[156]</a></sup> the Canary Islands,<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[157]</a></sup> the Balearic Islands,<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[158]</a></sup> and Aragon.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[159]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The autonomous communities have wide legislative and executive autonomy, with their own parliaments and regional governments. The distribution of powers may be different for every community, as laid out in their Statutes of Autonomy, since devolution was intended to be asymmetrical. Only two communities—the Basque Country and Navarre—have full fiscal autonomy. Beyond fiscal autonomy, the <i>nationalities</i>—Andalusia, the Basque Country, Catalonia, and Galicia—were devolved more powers than the rest of the communities, among them the ability of the regional president to dissolve the parliament and call for elections at any time. In addition, the Basque Country, Catalonia and Navarre have police corps of their own: <a href="/wiki/Ertzaintza" title="Ertzaintza">Ertzaintza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mossos_d%27Esquadra" title="Mossos d'Esquadra">Mossos d'Esquadra</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Polic%C3%ADa_Foral" title="Policía Foral">Policía Foral</a> respectively. Other communities have more limited forces or none at all, like the <i>Policía Autónoma Andaluza</i><sup id="cite_ref-cartujo_172-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cartujo-172">[160]</a></sup> in <a href="/wiki/Andalusia" title="Andalusia">Andalusia</a> or the <a href="/wiki/BESCAM" title="BESCAM">BESCAM</a> in Madrid. </p>
      <p>Nonetheless, recent amendments to existing Statutes of Autonomy or the promulgation of new Statutes altogether, have reduced the asymmetry between the powers originally granted to the <i>nationalities</i> and the rest of the regions. </p>
      <p>Finally, along with the 17 autonomous communities, two autonomous cities are also part of the State of Autonomies and are first-order territorial divisions: <a href="/wiki/Ceuta" title="Ceuta">Ceuta</a> and <a href="/wiki/Melilla" title="Melilla">Melilla</a>. These are two exclaves located in the northern African coast. </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Provinces_and_municipalities">Provinces and municipalities</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Spain" title="Provinces of Spain">Provinces of Spain</a> and <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Spain" title="Municipalities of Spain">Municipalities of Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Autonomous communities are divided into <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Spain" title="Provinces of Spain">provinces</a>, which served as their territorial building blocks. In turn, provinces are divided into <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Spain" title="Municipalities of Spain">municipalities</a>. The existence of both the provinces and the municipalities is guaranteed and protected by the constitution, not necessarily by the Statutes of Autonomy themselves. Municipalities are granted autonomy to manage their internal affairs, and provinces are the territorial divisions designed to carry out the activities of the State.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[161]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The current provincial division structure is based—with minor changes—on the <a href="/wiki/1833_territorial_division_of_Spain" title="1833 territorial division of Spain">1833 territorial division</a> by <a href="/wiki/Javier_de_Burgos" title="Javier de Burgos">Javier de Burgos</a>, and in all, the Spanish territory is divided into 50 provinces. The communities of Asturias, Cantabria, La Rioja, the Balearic Islands, Madrid, Murcia and Navarre are the only communities that comprise a single province, which is coextensive with the community itself. In these cases, the administrative institutions of the province are replaced by the governmental institutions of the community. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Spain" title="Economy of Spain">Economy of Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:BlueEurozone.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/BlueEurozone.svg/220px-BlueEurozone.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="235" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/BlueEurozone.svg/330px-BlueEurozone.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/BlueEurozone.svg/440px-BlueEurozone.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="645" data-file-height="690"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:BlueEurozone.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Spain is a member of the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">Schengen Area</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">Eurozone</a> and the <a href="/wiki/European_Single_Market" title="European Single Market">European Single Market</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Spain's capitalist <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a> is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">14th largest</a> worldwide and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_in_Europe_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of sovereign states in Europe by GDP (nominal)">4th largest</a> in the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">Eurozone</a>'s 4th largest. </p>
      <p>The centre-right government of former prime minister <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_Aznar" title="José María Aznar">José María Aznar</a> worked successfully to gain admission to the group of countries launching the <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">euro</a> in 1999. <a href="/wiki/Unemployment_in_Spain" title="Unemployment in Spain">Unemployment</a> stood at 17.1% in June 2017,<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[162]</a></sup> below Spain's early 1990s unemployment rate of at over 20%. The <a href="/wiki/Youth_unemployment_in_Spain" title="Youth unemployment in Spain">youth unemployment</a> rate (35% in March 2018) is extremely high compared to EU standards.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[163]</a></sup> Perennial weak points of Spain's economy include a large <a href="/wiki/Informal_economy" title="Informal economy">informal economy</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[164]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[165]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[166]</a></sup> and an education system which OECD reports place among the poorest for developed countries, together with the United States and UK.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[167]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>By the mid-1990s the economy had commenced the growth that had been disrupted by the global recession of the early 1990s. The strong economic growth helped the government to reduce the government debt as a percentage of GDP and Spain's high unemployment rate began to steadily decline. With the government budget in balance and inflation under control Spain was admitted into the Eurozone in 1999. </p>
      <p>Since the 1990s some Spanish companies have gained multinational status, often expanding their activities in culturally close Latin America. Spain is the second biggest foreign investor there, after the United States. Spanish companies have also expanded into Asia, especially China and India.<sup id="cite_ref-Economist2009bet_180-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Economist2009bet-180">[168]</a></sup> This early global expansion is a competitive advantage over its competitors and European neighbours. The reason for this early expansion is the booming interest towards Spanish language and culture in Asia and Africa and a corporate culture that learned to take risks in unstable markets. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Zubizuri,_Bilbao.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Zubizuri%2C_Bilbao.jpg/220px-Zubizuri%2C_Bilbao.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="136" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Zubizuri%2C_Bilbao.jpg/330px-Zubizuri%2C_Bilbao.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Zubizuri%2C_Bilbao.jpg/440px-Zubizuri%2C_Bilbao.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5615" data-file-height="3468"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Zubizuri,_Bilbao.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Abando" title="Abando">Abando</a> district, <a href="/wiki/Bilbao" title="Bilbao">Bilbao</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Spanish companies invested in fields like <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_commercialisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Renewable energy commercialisation">renewable energy commercialisation</a> (<a href="/wiki/Iberdrola" title="Iberdrola">Iberdrola</a> was the world's largest renewable energy operator<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[169]</a></sup>), technology companies like <a href="/wiki/Telef%C3%B3nica" title="Telefónica">Telefónica</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abengoa" title="Abengoa">Abengoa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mondragon_Corporation" title="Mondragon Corporation">Mondragon Corporation</a> (which is the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Worker_cooperative" title="Worker cooperative">worker-owned cooperative</a>), <a href="/wiki/Movistar" title="Movistar">Movistar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hisdesat" class="mw-redirect" title="Hisdesat">Hisdesat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indra_Sistemas" title="Indra Sistemas">Indra</a>, train manufacturers like <a href="/wiki/Construcciones_y_Auxiliar_de_Ferrocarriles" title="Construcciones y Auxiliar de Ferrocarriles">CAF</a>, <a href="/wiki/Talgo" title="Talgo">Talgo</a>, global corporations such as the textile company <a href="/wiki/Inditex" title="Inditex">Inditex</a>, petroleum companies like <a href="/wiki/Repsol" title="Repsol">Repsol</a> or <a href="/wiki/Cepsa" title="Cepsa">Cepsa</a> and infrastructure, with six of the ten biggest international construction firms specialising in transport being Spanish, like <a href="/wiki/Ferrovial" title="Ferrovial">Ferrovial</a>, <a href="/wiki/Acciona" title="Acciona">Acciona</a>, <a href="/wiki/Grupo_ACS" class="mw-redirect" title="Grupo ACS">ACS</a>, <a href="/wiki/Obrasc%C3%B3n_Huarte_Lain" title="Obrascón Huarte Lain">OHL</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fomento_de_Construcciones_y_Contratas" title="Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas">FCC</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Economist2009big_182-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Economist2009big-182">[170]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2005 the <a href="/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit" title="Economist Intelligence Unit">Economist Intelligence Unit</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Quality_of_life" title="Quality of life">quality of life</a> survey placed Spain among the top 10 in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[171]</a></sup> In 2013 the same survey (now called the "Where-to-be-born index"), ranked Spain 28th in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[172]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2010, the <a href="/wiki/Basque_Country_(autonomous_community)" title="Basque Country (autonomous community)">Basque</a> city of <a href="/wiki/Bilbao" title="Bilbao">Bilbao</a> was awarded with the <a href="/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew_World_City_Prize" class="mw-redirect" title="Lee Kuan Yew World City Prize">Lee Kuan Yew World City Prize</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[173]</a></sup> and its mayor at the time, <a href="/wiki/I%C3%B1aki_Azkuna" title="Iñaki Azkuna">Iñaki Azkuna</a>, was awarded the <a href="/wiki/World_Mayor" title="World Mayor">World Mayor</a> Prize in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[174]</a></sup> The Basque capital city of <a href="/wiki/Vitoria-Gasteiz" title="Vitoria-Gasteiz">Vitoria-Gasteiz</a> received the <a href="/wiki/European_Green_Capital_Award" title="European Green Capital Award">European Green Capital Award</a> in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[175]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Automotive_industry">Automotive industry</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_Spain" title="Automotive industry in Spain">Automotive industry in Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Factor%C3%ADa_de_Renault_en_Valladolid._Junta_de_Castilla_y_Le%C3%B3n._2018.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Factor%C3%ADa_de_Renault_en_Valladolid._Junta_de_Castilla_y_Le%C3%B3n._2018.jpg/220px-Factor%C3%ADa_de_Renault_en_Valladolid._Junta_de_Castilla_y_Le%C3%B3n._2018.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Factor%C3%ADa_de_Renault_en_Valladolid._Junta_de_Castilla_y_Le%C3%B3n._2018.jpg/330px-Factor%C3%ADa_de_Renault_en_Valladolid._Junta_de_Castilla_y_Le%C3%B3n._2018.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Factor%C3%ADa_de_Renault_en_Valladolid._Junta_de_Castilla_y_Le%C3%B3n._2018.jpg/440px-Factor%C3%ADa_de_Renault_en_Valladolid._Junta_de_Castilla_y_Le%C3%B3n._2018.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1100" data-file-height="731"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Factor%C3%ADa_de_Renault_en_Valladolid._Junta_de_Castilla_y_Le%C3%B3n._2018.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Renault factory in <a href="/wiki/Valladolid" title="Valladolid">Valladolid</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The automotive industry is one of the largest employers in the country. In 2015 Spain was the 8th largest automobile producer country in the world and the 2nd largest car manufacturer in Europe after Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-WSJ_188-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WSJ-188">[176]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>By 2016, the automotive industry was generating 8.7 percent of Spain's <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a>, employing about nine percent of the manufacturing industry.<sup id="cite_ref-WSJ_188-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WSJ-188">[176]</a></sup> By 2008 the automobile industry was the 2nd most exported industry<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[177]</a></sup> while in 2015 about 80% of the total production was for export.<sup id="cite_ref-WSJ_188-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WSJ-188">[176]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>German companies poured €4.8 billion into Spain in 2015, making the country the second-largest destination for German <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">foreign direct investment</a> behind only the U.S. The lion's share of that investment—€4 billion—went to the country's auto industry.<sup id="cite_ref-WSJ_188-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WSJ-188">[176]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture">Agriculture</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Spain" title="Agriculture in Spain">Agriculture in Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Crop areas were farmed in two highly diverse manners. Areas relying on non-irrigated cultivation (<i>secano</i>), which made up 85% of the entire crop area, depended solely on rainfall as a source of water. They included the humid regions of the north and the northwest, as well as vast arid zones that had not been irrigated. The much more productive regions devoted to irrigated cultivation (<i>regadío</i>) accounted for 3 million hectares in 1986, and the government hoped that this area would eventually double, as it already had doubled since 1950. Particularly noteworthy was the development in <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Almer%C3%ADa" title="Province of Almería">Almería</a>—one of the most arid and desolate provinces of Spain—of winter crops of various fruits and vegetables for export to Europe. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Vi%C3%B1edos_en_Bri%C3%B1as.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Vi%C3%B1edos_en_Bri%C3%B1as.jpg/220px-Vi%C3%B1edos_en_Bri%C3%B1as.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Vi%C3%B1edos_en_Bri%C3%B1as.jpg/330px-Vi%C3%B1edos_en_Bri%C3%B1as.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Vi%C3%B1edos_en_Bri%C3%B1as.jpg/440px-Vi%C3%B1edos_en_Bri%C3%B1as.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="768"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Vi%C3%B1edos_en_Bri%C3%B1as.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A <a href="/wiki/Vineyard" title="Vineyard">vineyard</a> in <a href="/wiki/Rioja_(wine)" title="Rioja (wine)">Rioja</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Though only about 17% of Spain's cultivated land was irrigated, it was estimated to be the source of between 40 and 45% of the gross value of crop production and of 50% of the value of agricultural exports. More than half of the irrigated area was planted in <a href="/wiki/Maize" title="Maize">corn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fruit_tree" title="Fruit tree">fruit trees</a>, and vegetables. Other agricultural products that benefited from irrigation included grapes, cotton, <a href="/wiki/Sugar_beet" title="Sugar beet">sugar beets</a>, potatoes, <a href="/wiki/Legume" title="Legume">legumes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Olive_tree" class="mw-redirect" title="Olive tree">olive trees</a>, mangos, <a href="/wiki/Strawberries" class="mw-redirect" title="Strawberries">strawberries</a>, tomatoes, and <a href="/wiki/Fodder" title="Fodder">fodder</a> grasses. Depending on the nature of the crop, it was possible to harvest two successive crops in the same year on about 10% of the country's irrigated land. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Citrus_fruit" class="mw-redirect" title="Citrus fruit">Citrus fruits</a>, vegetables, <a href="/wiki/Cereal_grain" class="mw-redirect" title="Cereal grain">cereal grains</a>, <a href="/wiki/Olive_oil" title="Olive oil">olive oil</a>, and wine—Spain's traditional agricultural products—continued to be important in the 1980s. In 1983 they represented 12%, 12%, 8%, 6%, and 4%, respectively, of the country's agricultural production. Because of the changed diet of an increasingly affluent population, there was a notable increase in the consumption of livestock, poultry, and <a href="/wiki/Dairy_product" title="Dairy product">dairy products</a>. Meat production for domestic consumption became the single most important agricultural activity, accounting for 30% of all farm-related production in 1983. Increased attention to livestock was the reason that Spain became a net importer of grains. Ideal growing conditions, combined with proximity to important north European markets, made citrus fruits Spain's leading export. Fresh vegetables and fruits produced through intensive irrigation farming also became important export commodities, as did <a href="/wiki/Sunflower_seed_oil" class="mw-redirect" title="Sunflower seed oil">sunflower seed oil</a> that was produced to compete with the more expensive olive oils in oversupply throughout the Mediterranean countries of the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Community</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Spain" title="Tourism in Spain">Tourism in Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Benidorm_-_Playa_de_Poniente_26.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Benidorm_-_Playa_de_Poniente_26.jpg/220px-Benidorm_-_Playa_de_Poniente_26.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="142" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Benidorm_-_Playa_de_Poniente_26.jpg/330px-Benidorm_-_Playa_de_Poniente_26.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Benidorm_-_Playa_de_Poniente_26.jpg/440px-Benidorm_-_Playa_de_Poniente_26.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2039" data-file-height="1320"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Benidorm_-_Playa_de_Poniente_26.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Benidorm" title="Benidorm">Benidorm</a>, one of Europe's largest coastal tourist destinations
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2017, Spain was the second most visited country in the world, recording 82 million tourists which marked the fifth consecutive year of record-beating numbers.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[178]</a></sup> The headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_Organization" title="World Tourism Organization">World Tourism Organization</a> are located in <a href="/wiki/Madrid" title="Madrid">Madrid</a>. </p>
      <p>Spain's geographic location, popular coastlines, diverse landscapes, historical legacy, vibrant culture, and excellent infrastructure has made the country's international tourist industry among the largest in the world. In the last five decades, international tourism in Spain has grown to become the second largest in the world in terms of spending, worth approximately 40&nbsp;billion Euros or about 5% of GDP in 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-guru_191-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-guru-191">[179]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[180]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Castile_and_Leon" class="mw-redirect" title="Castile and Leon">Castile and Leon</a> is the Spanish leader in <a href="/wiki/Rural_tourism" title="Rural tourism">rural tourism</a> linked to its environmental and architectural heritage. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Spain" title="Energy in Spain">Energy in Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Foto_a%C3%A9re_de_solnovas_y_torre_junio_2010.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Foto_a%C3%A9re_de_solnovas_y_torre_junio_2010.jpg/220px-Foto_a%C3%A9re_de_solnovas_y_torre_junio_2010.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="123" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Foto_a%C3%A9re_de_solnovas_y_torre_junio_2010.jpg/330px-Foto_a%C3%A9re_de_solnovas_y_torre_junio_2010.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Foto_a%C3%A9re_de_solnovas_y_torre_junio_2010.jpg/440px-Foto_a%C3%A9re_de_solnovas_y_torre_junio_2010.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3832" data-file-height="2139"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Foto_a%C3%A9re_de_solnovas_y_torre_junio_2010.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Photovoltaics" title="Photovoltaics">Photovoltaic</a> plants (foreground) and <a href="/wiki/Solar_thermal_energy" title="Solar thermal energy">solar thermal</a> plants (background) in the province of Seville
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2010 Spain became the <a href="/wiki/Solar_power_in_Spain" title="Solar power in Spain">solar power</a> world leader when it overtook the United States with a massive power station plant called <a href="/wiki/Alvarado_I" title="Alvarado I">La Florida</a>, near <a href="/wiki/Badajoz" title="Badajoz">Alvarado, Badajoz</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[181]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[182]</a></sup> Spain is also Europe's main producer of wind energy.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[183]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[184]</a></sup> In 2010 its wind turbines generated 42,976 GWh, which accounted for 16.4% of all electrical energy produced in Spain.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[185]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[186]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Graber2005_199-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Graber2005-199">[187]</a></sup> On 9 November 2010, wind energy reached an instantaneous historic peak covering 53% of mainland electricity demand<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[188]</a></sup> and generating an amount of energy that is equivalent to that of 14 <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_reactor" title="Nuclear reactor">nuclear reactors</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[189]</a></sup> Other renewable energies used in Spain are <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectric_power_plant" class="mw-redirect" title="Hydroelectric power plant">hydroelectric</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gasification_of_biomass" class="mw-redirect" title="Gasification of biomass">biomass</a> and <a href="/wiki/Marine_energy" title="Marine energy">marine</a> (2 power plants under construction).<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[190]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Non-renewable energy sources used in Spain are <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_plant" title="Nuclear power plant">nuclear</a> (8 operative reactors), <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas_power_plant" class="mw-redirect" title="Natural gas power plant">gas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coal_power_plant" class="mw-redirect" title="Coal power plant">coal</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Oil_power_plant" class="mw-redirect" title="Oil power plant">oil</a>. Fossil fuels together generated 58% of Spain's electricity in 2009, just below the OECD mean of 61%. Nuclear power generated another 19%, and wind and hydro about 12% each.<sup id="cite_ref-SverigeE_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SverigeE-203">[191]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Spain" title="Transport in Spain">Transport in Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Port_of_Valencia.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Port_of_Valencia.jpg/220px-Port_of_Valencia.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Port_of_Valencia.jpg/330px-Port_of_Valencia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Port_of_Valencia.jpg/440px-Port_of_Valencia.jpg 2x" data-file-width="768" data-file-height="512"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Port_of_Valencia.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Valencia" title="Port of Valencia">Port of Valencia</a>, one of the busiest in the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Banana" title="Golden Banana">Golden Banana</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Spanish road system is mainly centralised, with six highways connecting <a href="/wiki/Madrid" title="Madrid">Madrid</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Basque_Country_(autonomous_community)" title="Basque Country (autonomous community)">Basque Country</a>, <a href="/wiki/Catalonia" title="Catalonia">Catalonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Valencian_Community" title="Valencian Community">Valencia</a>, West <a href="/wiki/Andalusia" title="Andalusia">Andalusia</a>, Extremadura and <a href="/wiki/Galicia_(Spain)" title="Galicia (Spain)">Galicia</a>. Additionally, there are highways along the Atlantic (<a href="/wiki/Ferrol,_Spain" title="Ferrol, Spain">Ferrol</a> to <a href="/wiki/Vigo" title="Vigo">Vigo</a>), Cantabrian (<a href="/wiki/Oviedo" title="Oviedo">Oviedo</a> to <a href="/wiki/San_Sebasti%C3%A1n" title="San Sebastián">San Sebastián</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean</a> (<a href="/wiki/Girona" title="Girona">Girona</a> to <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A1diz" title="Cádiz">Cádiz</a>) coasts. Spain aims to put one&nbsp;million <a href="/wiki/Electric_car" title="Electric car">electric cars</a> on the road by 2014 as part of the government's plan to save energy and boost <a href="/wiki/Efficient_energy_use" title="Efficient energy use">energy efficiency</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[192]</a></sup> The former Minister of Industry <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Sebasti%C3%A1n_Gasc%C3%B3n" title="Miguel Sebastián Gascón">Miguel Sebastián</a> said that "the electric vehicle is the future and the engine of an industrial revolution."<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[193]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Spain has the most extensive high-speed rail network in Europe, and the second-most extensive in the world after China.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[194]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[195]</a></sup> As of 2019, Spain has a total of over 3,400&nbsp;km (2,112.66&nbsp;mi) of high-speed tracks<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[196]</a></sup> linking <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A1laga" title="Málaga">Málaga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seville" title="Seville">Seville</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madrid" title="Madrid">Madrid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barcelona" title="Barcelona">Barcelona</a>, <a href="/wiki/Valencia" title="Valencia">Valencia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Valladolid" title="Valladolid">Valladolid</a>, with the trains operated at commercial speeds up to 310&nbsp;km/h (190&nbsp;mph).<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[197]</a></sup> On average, the Spanish high-speed train is the fastest one in the world, followed by the Japanese <a href="/wiki/Shinkansen" title="Shinkansen">bullet train</a> and the French <a href="/wiki/TGV" title="TGV">TGV</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[198]</a></sup> Regarding punctuality, it is second in the world (98.5% on-time arrival) after the Japanese Shinkansen (99%).<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[199]</a></sup> Should the aims of the ambitious <a href="/wiki/AVE" title="AVE">AVE</a> programme (Spanish high speed trains) be met, by 2020 Spain will have 7,000&nbsp;km (4,300&nbsp;mi) of high-speed trains linking almost all provincial cities to Madrid in less than three hours and Barcelona within four hours. </p>
      <p>There are 47 public airports in Spain. The busiest one is the <a href="/wiki/Madrid_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Madrid Airport">airport of Madrid</a> (Barajas), with 50&nbsp;million passengers in 2011, being the <a href="/wiki/World%27s_busiest_airports_by_passenger_traffic" class="mw-redirect" title="World's busiest airports by passenger traffic">world's 15th busiest airport</a>, as well as the European Union's fourth busiest. The <a href="/wiki/Barcelona_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Barcelona Airport">airport of Barcelona</a> (El Prat) is also important, with 35&nbsp;million passengers in 2011, being the world's 31st-busiest airport. Other main airports are located in <a href="/wiki/Palma_de_Mallorca_Airport" title="Palma de Mallorca Airport">Majorca</a> (23&nbsp;million passengers), <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A1laga_Airport" title="Málaga Airport">Málaga</a> (13&nbsp;million passengers), <a href="/wiki/Gran_Canaria_Airport" title="Gran Canaria Airport">Las Palmas (Gran Canaria)</a> (11&nbsp;million passengers), <a href="/wiki/Alicante_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Alicante Airport">Alicante</a> (10&nbsp;million passengers) and smaller, with the number of passengers between 4 and 10 million, for example <a href="/wiki/Tenerife_South_Airport" title="Tenerife South Airport">Tenerife</a> (two airports), <a href="/wiki/Valencia_Airport" title="Valencia Airport">Valencia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seville_Airport" title="Seville Airport">Seville</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bilbao_Airport" title="Bilbao Airport">Bilbao</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ibiza_Airport" title="Ibiza Airport">Ibiza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lanzarote_Airport" title="Lanzarote Airport">Lanzarote</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fuerteventura_Airport" title="Fuerteventura Airport">Fuerteventura</a>. Also, more than 30 airports with the number of passengers below 4 million. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Spain" title="Science and technology in Spain">Science and technology in Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ing_telescopes_sunset_la_palma_july_2001.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Ing_telescopes_sunset_la_palma_july_2001.jpg/220px-Ing_telescopes_sunset_la_palma_july_2001.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Ing_telescopes_sunset_la_palma_july_2001.jpg/330px-Ing_telescopes_sunset_la_palma_july_2001.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Ing_telescopes_sunset_la_palma_july_2001.jpg/440px-Ing_telescopes_sunset_la_palma_july_2001.jpg 2x" data-file-width="737" data-file-height="491"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ing_telescopes_sunset_la_palma_july_2001.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Roque_de_los_Muchachos_Observatory" title="Roque de los Muchachos Observatory">Roque de los Muchachos Observatory</a>, <a href="/wiki/Instituto_de_Astrof%C3%ADsica_de_Canarias" title="Instituto de Astrofísica de Canarias">Instituto de Astrofísica de Canarias</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In the 19th and 20th centuries, science in Spain was held back by severe political instability and consequent economic underdevelopment. Despite the conditions, some important scientists and engineers emerged. The most notable were <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Servet" class="mw-redirect" title="Miguel Servet">Miguel Servet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Santiago_Ram%C3%B3n_y_Cajal" title="Santiago Ramón y Cajal">Santiago Ramón y Cajal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Narc%C3%ADs_Monturiol" title="Narcís Monturiol">Narcís Monturiol</a>, <a href="/wiki/Celedonio_Calatayud" title="Celedonio Calatayud">Celedonio Calatayud</a>, <a href="/wiki/Juan_de_la_Cierva" title="Juan de la Cierva">Juan de la Cierva</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_Torres_y_Quevedo" title="Leonardo Torres y Quevedo">Leonardo Torres y Quevedo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Margarita_Salas" title="Margarita Salas">Margarita Salas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Severo_Ochoa" title="Severo Ochoa">Severo Ochoa</a>. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Consejo_Superior_de_Investigaciones_Cient%C3%ADficas" class="mw-redirect" title="Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Científicas">Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Científicas</a> (CSIC) is the leading public agency dedicated to scientific research in the country. It ranked as the 5th top governmental scientific institution worldwide (and 32nd overall) in the 2018 SCImago Institutions Rankings.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[200]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since 2006, the <a href="/wiki/Mobile_World_Congress" title="Mobile World Congress">Mobile World Congress</a> has taken place in <a href="/wiki/Barcelona" title="Barcelona">Barcelona</a>. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Spain" title="Demographics of Spain">Demographics of Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Spanish_autonomous_communities_by_population" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Spanish autonomous communities by population">List of Spanish autonomous communities by population</a>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2019, the population of Spain officially reached 47&nbsp;million people, as recorded by the <i>Padrón municipal</i> (Spain's Municipal Register).<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[201]</a></sup> Spain's population density, at 91/km<sup>2</sup> (235/sq mi), is lower than that of most Western European countries and its distribution across the country is very unequal. With the exception of the region surrounding the capital, <a href="/wiki/Madrid" title="Madrid">Madrid</a>, the most populated areas lie around the coast. The population of Spain has risen 2 1/2 times since 1900, when it stood at 18.6&nbsp;million, principally due to the spectacular demographic boom in the 1960s and early 1970s.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[202]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Spain_1950-2014_Population_pyramid.gif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Spain_1950-2014_Population_pyramid.gif/220px-Spain_1950-2014_Population_pyramid.gif" decoding="async" width="220" height="107" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Spain_1950-2014_Population_pyramid.gif/330px-Spain_1950-2014_Population_pyramid.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Spain_1950-2014_Population_pyramid.gif/440px-Spain_1950-2014_Population_pyramid.gif 2x" data-file-width="954" data-file-height="465"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Spain_1950-2014_Population_pyramid.gif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Population_pyramid" title="Population pyramid">Population pyramid</a> of Spain from 1950 to 2014
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2017, the average <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> (TFR) across Spain was 1.33 children born per woman,<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[203]</a></sup> one of the lowest in the world, below the replacement rate of 2.1, it remains considerably below the high of 5.11 children born per woman in 1865.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[204]</a></sup> Spain subsequently has one of the oldest populations in the world, with the average age of 43.1 years.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[205]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Native <a href="/wiki/Spaniards" title="Spaniards">Spaniards</a> make up 88% of the total population of Spain. After the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_territories_by_fertility_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries and territories by fertility rate">birth rate</a> plunged in the 1980s and Spain's population growth rate dropped, the population again trended upward initially upon the return of many Spaniards who had emigrated to other European countries during the 1970s, and more recently, fuelled by large numbers of immigrants who make up 12% of the population. The immigrants originate mainly in Latin America (39%), North Africa (16%), Eastern Europe (15%), and <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Sub-Saharan Africa">Sub-Saharan Africa</a> (4%).<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[206]</a></sup> In 2005, Spain instituted a three-month amnesty programme through which certain hitherto undocumented aliens were granted legal residency.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[207]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2008, Spain granted citizenship to 84,170 persons, mostly to people from Ecuador, Colombia and Morocco.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[208]</a></sup> A sizeable portion of foreign residents in Spain also comes from other Western and Central European countries. These are mostly British, French, German, Dutch, and Norwegian. They reside primarily on the Mediterranean coast and the Balearic islands, where many choose to live their retirement or <a href="/wiki/Telecommute" class="mw-redirect" title="Telecommute">telecommute</a>. </p>
      <p>Substantial populations descended from Spanish colonists and immigrants exist in other parts of the world, most notably in Latin America. Beginning in the late 15th century, large numbers of Iberian colonists settled in what became Latin America and at present most <a href="/wiki/White_Latin_American" class="mw-redirect" title="White Latin American">white Latin Americans</a> (who make up about one-third of Latin America's population) are of Spanish or Portuguese origin. Around 240,000 Spaniards emigrated in the 16th century, mostly to <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">Mexico</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[209]</a></sup> Another 450,000 left in the 17th century.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[210]</a></sup> The estimate between 1492 and 1832 is 1.86 million.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[211]</a></sup> Between 1846 and 1932 it is estimated that nearly 5&nbsp;million Spaniards emigrated to the Americas, especially to <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[212]</a></sup> Approximately two million Spaniards migrated to other Western European countries between 1960 and 1975. During the same period perhaps 300,000 went to Latin America.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[213]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanisation">Urbanisation</span></h3> 
      <table class="navbox"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr>

        <tr style="text-align:right;"> 
         <td>3</td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Valencia" title="Valencia">Valencia</a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Valencian_Community" title="Valencian Community">Valencia</a></td> 
         <td>1,551,585</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;">1.5 – 2.3 m<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[218]</a></sup> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr style="text-align:right;"> 
         <td>4</td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Seville" title="Seville">Seville</a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Andalusia" title="Andalusia">Andalusia</a></td> 
         <td>1,294,867</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;">1.2 – 1.3 m </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr style="text-align:right;"> 
         <td>5</td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/M%C3%A1laga" title="Málaga">Málaga</a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Andalusia" title="Andalusia">Andalusia</a></td> 
         <td>953,251</td> 
         <td style="background:silver;"> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr style="text-align:right;"> 
         <td>6</td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Bilbao" title="Bilbao">Bilbao</a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Basque_Country_(autonomous_community)" title="Basque Country (autonomous community)">Basque Country</a></td> 
         <td>910,578</td> 
         <td style="background:silver;"> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr style="text-align:right;"> 
         <td>7</td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Oviedo" title="Oviedo">Oviedo</a>–<a href="/wiki/Gij%C3%B3n" title="Gijón">Gijón</a>–<a href="/wiki/Avil%C3%A9s" title="Avilés">Avilés</a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Asturias" title="Asturias">Asturias</a></td> 
         <td>835,053</td> 
         <td style="background:silver;"> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr style="text-align:right;"> 
         <td>8</td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Zaragoza" title="Zaragoza">Zaragoza</a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Aragon" title="Aragon">Aragon</a></td> 
         <td>746,152</td> 
         <td style="background:silver;"> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr style="text-align:right;"> 
         <td>9</td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Alicante" title="Alicante">Alicante</a>–<a href="/wiki/Elche" title="Elche">Elche</a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Valencian_Community" title="Valencian Community">Valencia</a></td> 
         <td>698,662</td> 
         <td style="background:silver;"> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr style="text-align:right;"> 
         <td>10</td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Murcia" title="Murcia">Murcia</a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Region_of_Murcia" title="Region of Murcia">Murcia</a></td> 
         <td>643,854</td> 
         <td style="background:silver;"> </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Peoples">Peoples</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Spanish_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Spanish people">Spanish people</a> and <a href="/wiki/National_and_regional_identity_in_Spain" title="National and regional identity in Spain">National and regional identity in Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Constitution_of_1978" class="mw-redirect" title="Spanish Constitution of 1978">Spanish Constitution of 1978</a>, in its second article, recognises several contemporary <a href="/wiki/Polity" title="Polity">entities</a>—<i><a href="/wiki/Nationalities_and_regions_of_Spain" title="Nationalities and regions of Spain">nationalities</a></i>—<sup id="cite_ref-Nationalities_231-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nationalities-231">[m]</a></sup> and regions, within the context of the Spanish nation. </p>
      <p>Spain has been described as a <i>de facto</i> <a href="/wiki/Plurinationalism" title="Plurinationalism">plurinational state</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[219]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[220]</a></sup> The identity of Spain rather accrues of an overlap of different territorial and ethnolinguistic identities than of a sole Spanish identity. In some cases some of the territorial identities may conflict with the dominant Spanish culture. Distinct traditional identities within Spain include the <a href="/wiki/Basque_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Basque people">Basques</a>, <a href="/wiki/Catalan_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Catalan people">Catalans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Galician_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Galician people">Galicians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andalusians" title="Andalusians">Andalusians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Valencian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Valencian people">Valencians</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[221]</a></sup> although to some extent all of the 17 autonomous communities may claim a distinct local identity. </p>
      <p>It is this last feature of "shared identity" between the more local level or autonomous community and the Spanish level which makes the identity question in Spain complex and far from univocal. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Minority_groups">Minority groups</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Mayer_recibe_la_bandera_gitana_en_el_D%C3%ADa_de_las_gitanas_y_gitanos_de_Madrid_03.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Mayer_recibe_la_bandera_gitana_en_el_D%C3%ADa_de_las_gitanas_y_gitanos_de_Madrid_03.jpg/220px-Mayer_recibe_la_bandera_gitana_en_el_D%C3%ADa_de_las_gitanas_y_gitanos_de_Madrid_03.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Mayer_recibe_la_bandera_gitana_en_el_D%C3%ADa_de_las_gitanas_y_gitanos_de_Madrid_03.jpg/330px-Mayer_recibe_la_bandera_gitana_en_el_D%C3%ADa_de_las_gitanas_y_gitanos_de_Madrid_03.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Mayer_recibe_la_bandera_gitana_en_el_D%C3%ADa_de_las_gitanas_y_gitanos_de_Madrid_03.jpg/440px-Mayer_recibe_la_bandera_gitana_en_el_D%C3%ADa_de_las_gitanas_y_gitanos_de_Madrid_03.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="1000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Mayer_recibe_la_bandera_gitana_en_el_D%C3%ADa_de_las_gitanas_y_gitanos_de_Madrid_03.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Celebration of the Romani Day on 24 May 2018 in Madrid
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Spain has a number of descendants of populations from former colonies, especially Latin America and North Africa. Smaller numbers of immigrants from several <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan" class="mw-redirect" title="Sub-Saharan">Sub-Saharan</a> countries have recently been settling in Spain. There are also sizeable numbers of Asian immigrants, most of whom are of Middle Eastern, <a href="/wiki/South_Asian" class="mw-redirect" title="South Asian">South Asian</a> and Chinese origin. The single largest group of immigrants are European; represented by large numbers of Romanians, Britons, <a href="/wiki/Germans" title="Germans">Germans</a>, French and others.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[222]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The arrival of the <i><a href="/wiki/Roma_in_Spain" class="mw-redirect" title="Roma in Spain">gitanos</a></i>, a <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">Romani people</a>, began in the 16th century; estimates of the Spanish Roma population range from 750,000 to over one million.<sup id="cite_ref-Diagnostico_Social_de_la_Comunidad_Gitana_en_Espana_–_CIS_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Diagnostico_Social_de_la_Comunidad_Gitana_en_Espana_–_CIS-236">[223]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[224]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[225]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-immigration_239-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-immigration-239">[226]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[227]</a></sup> There are also the <i><a href="/wiki/Merchero" class="mw-redirect" title="Merchero">mercheros</a></i> (also <i>quinquis</i>), a formerly nomadic minority group. Their origin is unclear. </p>
      <p>Historically, <a href="/wiki/Sephardi_Jews" title="Sephardi Jews">Sephardi Jews</a> and <a href="/wiki/Morisco" title="Morisco">Moriscos</a> are the main minority groups originated in Spain and with a contribution to Spanish culture.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[228]</a></sup> The Spanish government is offering Spanish nationality to Sephardi Jews.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[229]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Immigration">Immigration</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Spain" title="Immigration to Spain">Immigration to Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Distribuci%C3%B3n_de_la_poblaci%C3%B3n_extranjera_en_Espa%C3%B1a_(2005).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Distribuci%C3%B3n_de_la_poblaci%C3%B3n_extranjera_en_Espa%C3%B1a_%282005%29.png/220px-Distribuci%C3%B3n_de_la_poblaci%C3%B3n_extranjera_en_Espa%C3%B1a_%282005%29.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Distribuci%C3%B3n_de_la_poblaci%C3%B3n_extranjera_en_Espa%C3%B1a_%282005%29.png/330px-Distribuci%C3%B3n_de_la_poblaci%C3%B3n_extranjera_en_Espa%C3%B1a_%282005%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Distribuci%C3%B3n_de_la_poblaci%C3%B3n_extranjera_en_Espa%C3%B1a_%282005%29.png/440px-Distribuci%C3%B3n_de_la_poblaci%C3%B3n_extranjera_en_Espa%C3%B1a_%282005%29.png 2x" data-file-width="813" data-file-height="539"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Distribuci%C3%B3n_de_la_poblaci%C3%B3n_extranjera_en_Espa%C3%B1a_(2005).png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Distribution of the foreign population in Spain in 2005 by percentage
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to the official Spanish statistics (<a href="/wiki/Instituto_Nacional_de_Estad%C3%ADstica_(Spain)" title="Instituto Nacional de Estadística (Spain)">INE</a>) there were 5.4&nbsp;million foreign residents in Spain in 2020 (11.4%)<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[230]</a></sup> while all citizens born outside of Spain were 7.2&nbsp;million in 2020, 15.23% of the total population.<sup id="cite_ref-ine.es_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ine.es-7">[4]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to residence permit data for 2011, more than 860,000 were Romanian, about 770,000 were <a href="/wiki/Moroccan_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Moroccan people">Moroccan</a>, approximately 390,000 were British, and 360,000 were <a href="/wiki/Ecuadorian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Ecuadorian people">Ecuadorian</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[231]</a></sup> Other sizeable foreign communities are Colombian, Bolivian, German, Italian, <a href="/wiki/Bulgarians" title="Bulgarians">Bulgarian</a>, and Chinese. There are more than 200,000 migrants from Sub-Saharan Africa living in Spain, principally <a href="/wiki/Senegalese_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Senegalese people">Senegaleses</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nigerian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Nigerian people">Nigerians</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[232]</a></sup> Since 2000, Spain has experienced high <a href="/wiki/Population_growth" title="Population growth">population growth</a> as a result of immigration flows, despite a birth rate that is only half the replacement level. This sudden and ongoing inflow of immigrants, particularly those arriving illegally by sea, has caused noticeable social tension.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[233]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Within the EU, Spain had the 2nd highest immigration rate in percentage terms after <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">Cyprus</a>, but by a great margin, the highest in absolute numbers, up to 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[234]</a></sup> The number of immigrants in Spain had grown up from 500,000 people in 1996 to 5.2&nbsp;million in 2008 out of a total population of 46&nbsp;million.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[235]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[236]</a></sup> In 2005 alone, a regularisation programme increased the legal immigrant population by 700,000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[237]</a></sup> There are a number of reasons for the high level of immigration, including Spain's cultural ties with Latin America, its geographical position, the porosity of its borders, the large size of its underground economy and the strength of the agricultural and construction sectors, which demand more low cost labour than can be offered by the national workforce. </p>
      <p>Another statistically significant factor is the large number of residents of EU origin typically retiring to Spain's Mediterranean coast. In fact, Spain was Europe's largest absorber of migrants from 2002 to 2007, with its immigrant population more than doubling as 2.5&nbsp;million people arrived.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[238]</a></sup> In 2008, prior to the onset of the economic crisis, the <i>Financial Times</i> reported that Spain was the most favoured destination for Western Europeans considering a move from their own country and seeking jobs elsewhere in the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[239]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2008, the government instituted a "Plan of Voluntary Return" which encouraged unemployed immigrants from outside the EU to return to their home countries and receive several incentives, including the right to keep their unemployment benefits and transfer whatever they contributed to the Spanish Social Security.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[240]</a></sup> The programme had little effect; during its first two months, just 1,400 immigrants took up the offer.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[241]</a></sup> What the programme failed to do, the sharp and prolonged economic crisis has done from 2010 to 2011 in that tens of thousands of immigrants have left the country due to lack of jobs. In 2011 alone, more than half a million people left Spain.<sup id="cite_ref-emigracion_255-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-emigracion-255">[242]</a></sup> For the first time in decades the net migration rate was expected to be negative, and nine out of 10 emigrants were foreigners.<sup id="cite_ref-emigracion_255-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-emigracion-255">[242]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Spain" title="Languages of Spain">Languages of Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Spain_languages-en.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Spain_languages-en.svg/300px-Spain_languages-en.svg.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="212" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Spain_languages-en.svg/450px-Spain_languages-en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Spain_languages-en.svg/600px-Spain_languages-en.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1488" data-file-height="1052"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Languages_of_Spain.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Languages of Spain
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Spain is legally multilingual,<sup id="cite_ref-conversi_256-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-conversi-256">[243]</a></sup> and the constitution establishes that the nation will protect "all Spaniards and the peoples of Spain in the exercise of human rights, their cultures and traditions, languages and institutions.<sup id="cite_ref-preamble_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-preamble-257">[244]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a> (<i>español</i>)— recognised in the constitution as <a href="/wiki/Names_given_to_the_Spanish_language" title="Names given to the Spanish language">Castilian</a> (<i>castellano</i>)—is the official language of the entire country, and it is the right and duty of every Spaniard to know the language. The constitution also establishes that "the other Spanish languages"—that is, the other languages of Spain—will also be official in their respective autonomous communities in accordance to their <a href="/wiki/Statute_of_Autonomy" title="Statute of Autonomy">Statutes</a>, their organic regional legislations, and that the "richness of the distinct linguistic modalities of Spain represents a patrimony which will be the object of special respect and protection."<sup id="cite_ref-third_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-third-258">[245]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The other official languages of Spain, co-official with Spanish are: </p> 
      <ul>
       <li><a href="/wiki/Catalan_language" title="Catalan language">Catalan</a> (<i>català</i> or <i>valencià</i>) in <a href="/wiki/Catalonia" title="Catalonia">Catalonia</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Valencian_Community" title="Valencian Community">Valencian Community</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Balearic_Islands" title="Balearic Islands">Balearic Islands</a>;</li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Galician_language" title="Galician language">Galician</a> (<i>galego</i>) in <a href="/wiki/Galicia_(Spain)" title="Galicia (Spain)">Galicia</a>;</li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Basque_language" title="Basque language">Basque</a> (<i>euskara</i>) in the <a href="/wiki/Basque_Country_(autonomous_community)" title="Basque Country (autonomous community)">Basque Country</a> and <a href="/wiki/Navarre" title="Navarre">Navarre</a>; and</li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Occitan_language" title="Occitan language">Occitan</a> (<i>aranés</i>) in <a href="/wiki/Catalonia" title="Catalonia">Catalonia</a>.</li>
      </ul> 
      <p>As a percentage of the general population of all Spain, Spanish is natively spoken by 74%, Catalan by 17%, Galician by 7% and Basque by 2% of all Spaniards. Occitan is spoken by less than 5,000 people, only in the small region of <i><a href="/wiki/Val_d%27Aran" title="Val d'Aran">Val d'Aran</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[246]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Other <a href="/wiki/Romance_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Romance language">Romance</a> <a href="/wiki/Minority_languages" class="mw-redirect" title="Minority languages">minority languages</a>, though not official, have special recognition, such as the <a href="/wiki/Astur-Leonese_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Astur-Leonese language">Astur-Leonese language</a> (<i>asturianu</i>, <i>bable</i><sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[247]</a></sup> or <i>llionés</i>) in <a href="/wiki/Asturias" title="Asturias">Asturias</a> and in northwestern <a href="/wiki/Castile_and_Le%C3%B3n" title="Castile and León">Castile and León</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Aragonese_language" title="Aragonese language">Aragonese</a> (<i>aragonés</i>) in <a href="/wiki/Aragon" title="Aragon">Aragon</a>. </p>
      <p>In the North African Spanish autonomous city of <a href="/wiki/Melilla" title="Melilla">Melilla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Riff_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Riff language">Riff Berber</a> is spoken by a significant part of the population. Similarly, in <a href="/wiki/Ceuta" title="Ceuta">Ceuta</a> <a href="/wiki/Moroccan_Arabic" title="Moroccan Arabic">Darija Arabic</a> is spoken by a significant percentage of the population. In the tourist areas of the Mediterranean coast and the islands, English and German are widely spoken by tourists, foreign residents, and tourism workers.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[248]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Spain" title="Education in Spain">Education in Spain</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:UPF-Poblenou.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/UPF-Poblenou.JPG/220px-UPF-Poblenou.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="331" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/UPF-Poblenou.JPG/330px-UPF-Poblenou.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/UPF-Poblenou.JPG/440px-UPF-Poblenou.JPG 2x" data-file-width="665" data-file-height="1000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:UPF-Poblenou.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Poblenou Campus, <a href="/wiki/Universitat_Pompeu_Fabra" class="mw-redirect" title="Universitat Pompeu Fabra">Universitat Pompeu Fabra</a> – Barcelona
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>State education in Spain is free and compulsory from the age of six to sixteen. The current education system is regulated by the 2006 educational law, LOE (<i>Ley Orgánica de Educación</i>), or Fundamental Law for the Education.<sup id="cite_ref-LOE_juridicas_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LOE_juridicas-262">[249]</a></sup> In 2014, the LOE was partially modified by the newer and controversial LOMCE law (<i>Ley Orgánica para la Mejora de la Calidad Educativa</i>), or Fundamental Law for the Improvement of the Education System, commonly called <i>Ley Wert</i> (Wert Law).<sup id="cite_ref-LOMCE_juridicas_263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LOMCE_juridicas-263">[250]</a></sup> Since 1970 to 2014, Spain has had seven different educational laws (LGE, LOECE, LODE, LOGSE, LOPEG, LOE and LOMCE).<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[251]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The levels of education are preschool education, primary education,<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[252]</a></sup> secondary education<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[253]</a></sup> and post-16 education.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[254]</a></sup> In regards to the professional development education or the vocational education, there are three levels besides the university degrees: the <i>Formación Profesional Básica</i> (basic vocational education); the <i>Ciclo Formativo de Grado Medio</i> or <i>CFGM</i> (medium level vocation education) which can be studied after studying the secondary education, and the <i>Ciclo Formativo de Grado Superior</i> or <i>CFGS</i> (higher level vocational education), which can be studied after studying the post-16 education level.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[255]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_Spain" title="Health care in Spain">Health care in Spain</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abortion_in_Spain" title="Abortion in Spain">Abortion in Spain</a>
      </div>
